pill.title: Introduction
pill.content:
In Colombia there are countless cultural manifestations that express the ethnic and religious variety of customs, traditions and ways of life of its population, as well as its natural wealth and diversity of climates, geographies and landscapes, among others.

 

The joropo is one of the traditional forms of music and dance that basically identifies the Venezuelan and Colombian. Formerly "Joropo" could refer to a party and with the passing of time it has come to be identified rather as a form of music and dance.

pill.title: What is the Joropo?
pill.content:
Joropo is called a musical genre and traditional dance from Venezuela and Colombia. Its great diversity is manifested in different subregional typologies.

 

Joropo is a multivocal-polysemic term. For the cultists of rural areas, the word designates more to the dance party or event, than to the music or the choreography itself.

 

The joropo is one of the traditional forms of music and dance that basically identifies the Venezuelan and the Colombian from the eastern plains. Formerly "joropo" could refer to a party and with the passage of time it has come to be identified rather as a form of music and dance.

pill.title: Origin stories of the Joropo
pill.content:
Roots:

 

The origin of the joropo is Spanish fandango and Arabic melismatic music (group of notes sung on the same syllable).

 

According to the musicologist and researcher of Venezuelan and Caribbean music Rafael Salazar, «great students of musicology, such as Alejo Carpentier, consider that the fandango is a fecundatory black-African dance, originating from Guinea, which arrived in the Antilles from the dispersal of slaves forcibly brought to America for the harsh tasks of agriculture and mining. '

 

The fandango gained strength in the Iberian Peninsula thanks to the voyages of the conquerors, who took it from one place to another with its variants and Afro-American and peasant fusions.

 

In 1640 the Council of Castile prohibited fandango and other dances, calling them "amulatadas indianas". The joropo encloses in the fandango its Afro-American origin with small indigenous contributions. The first fandangos arrived in Caracas at the beginning of the seventeenth century, they were played in the evenings of the great cacaos in the capital's haciendas and were performed with instruments such as the bandurria, the instrument, the harpsichord and the bandola.

 

Etymology:

 

The word "joropo" comes from the Arabic "xarop" which means "syrup" and is related to the Mexican syrups from Guadalajara. There are those who say that the joropo is a Caribbean voice; likewise, there are people who maintain that it comes from Quechua.

pill.title: Stories of the History of the Joropo
pill.content:
It is the most representative folk dance of the Colombian-Venezuelan Plains; It is one of the folk dances that presents the typical Spanish survival, engendered in flamenco and Andalusian dances, as demonstrated by their footwork.

 

The dance that identifies the plainsman is the joropo. In this dance the llanero dances manifest his haughtiness, gallantry, machismo and some activities of his natural environment.

 

It is probable that the zapateos of the flamenco and Andalusian dances have influenced the initial conformation of our joropo, but with all the elements that they gave in the fusion of cultures, the joropo and the zapateo is special, they took root in our environment adapting and modified according to the interests and feelings of our communities.

 

Therefore, "our joropo" is a corral dance, proper for the recreation of our people, the llanero people, with which their popular, family, religious and cultural festivals are celebrated.

 

It is also said that the word joropo has as its antecedent the place where they met to dance and celebrate, formerly called "SOROPO" which were huts or ranches where they lived, but it was also a place for meetings and celebration.

pill.title: Stories of the History of the Joropo in the depart
pill.content: In Casanare it is said that it was the Indians from there who gave rise to this word. When they got together and for whatever reason the festivities were suspended, the most enthusiastic came out shouting: joropo, joropo, more joropo; These is a word of Arabic origin, which comes from xarop, syrup.

pill.title: Joropo Regional Variants
pill.content:
The joropo is the typical Colombian-Venezuelan dance and music, however, each region has a particular way of interpreting it, incorporating not only different themes and sounds, according to each region, but also the use of different instruments that will give the intonation. and characteristic musicality for each of these regions.


    • Joropo Central or Tuyero:

 

The Joropo Central is played with metal string harps, maracas and buche (voice), the cuatro as an accompanying instrument disappears which gives rise to a more melodious but less rhythmic sound.

pill.title: Joropo Regional Variants
pill.content:
• Joropo Oriental:

 

In the history of the Oriental Joropo, other instruments such as the guitar and the bandolin, the cuatro and sometimes the accordion and sometimes the cuereta, which is a type of small accordion of European origin, can be added. The oriental joropo is also called blow.

pill.title: Joropo Regional Variants
pill.content:
• Joropo Guayanés:

 

Product of the interaction of llaneros and orientals in the Bolívar state of Venezuela, specifically in Ciudad Bolívar. It is executed with the guayanese bandola (with eight metallic strings), the cuatro and the maracas. El Seis Guayanés, la Josa and Rompeluto stand out among the most famous guayanese joropos.

pill.title: Joropo Regional Variants
pill.content:
• Joropo Larense:

 

Originally from the Central-Western region of Venezuela, mainly states Lara, Portuguesa (sierra de Portuguesa) and Yaracuy. Played by a variety of string instruments (Cuatro, Medio Cinco, Cinco y Seis) that together with Tambora and Maracas produce a very particular and unique sound among other Venezuelan joropos. In the dance the number of members is six couples.

pill.title: Joropo Regional Variants
pill.content:
• Joropo Andino:

 

Joropo mainly executed in the states of Táchira and Mérida. This type of Joropo has two basic forms, the corrido and the galley. Generally, the Andean joropo is slow, adapted to the mountain landscape. It is played with violin, mandolin, tachirense bandolin, guitar, cuatro and tiple. Famous Andean joropos are the Pato bombiao, Perra Baya, Guariconga and Molinera.

pill.title: Colombian Llanero Joropo
pill.content:
The origin of the joropo goes back to the galerones, parties in which the waltz and waltz vueltiao were danced, which later led to the joropo and that is why the first step of the joropo is called valsiao. Originally, the joropo was a family party animated by music, song and dance with the pitanza, which comes from the plains of Venezuela and spread to Colombia in times of the conquest.

 

The small step of the joropo is intended to simulate the galloping of the rider on the plains; it is the rhythm where the llanero expresses his own sanguine impulses, and where he expresses his true indigenous values. The song of the history of the joropo expresses stories in verse about daily aspects of the life of the llanero; songs with various alterations in the tones and where flamenco songs are remembered.

question.question: ¿Is the joropo a rhythm associated with the region?

pill.title: Curiosities
pill.content:
Did you know…
 

The joropo llanero is associated with the rough work of herding the cattle, the ironwork, the rope. «When you have to link a rebellious horse, a bighorn horse, or you are also going to take the herd through the pasture, that Joropo is influenced by the rough work of the Llano. It's called Joropo Recio: a rougher song when played, more virtuosic. From a song thrown to the wind, as the llaneros throw when the one that is herding the cattle. Shout for the herd to advance or in communication with the cabestrero ... you hear that in the llaneros joropos »

pill.title: Introduction
pill.content:
The joropo is a musical genre and traditional dance of Colombia and Venezuela.

 

The joropo is part of the ternary music of the colonial Caribbean, being directly related to the Son Jarocho and Son Huasteco of Mexico, the Mejorana of Panama, among others. These musical expressions developed during the colonial period with influences from Baroque music and inter-oceanic trade.

 

Until the middle of the 20th century, and as far as the plains region of Venezuela and the Eastern Plains of Colombia are concerned, the word joropo referred to a social event -almost a fair- lasting from a few hours to a whole week. People from the locality or people coming from various places, generally attracted by commercial exchange, participated in the event, where the central event was the music, the dance and the contrapunteos. The music of the joropo llanero was provided by a basic ensemble composed of harp, maracas and singing. If there was no harp, it was substituted by a bandola or violin.

pill.title: Origin of the Harp
pill.content:
Etymology:

 

This term etymologically is composed of the French "harpe" and in turn from the Old High German "har(p)fe and the Germanic "harpō".
 

Roots:

 

The harp is a very ancient instrument, the first traces were found in Iran, around 3500 BC. Then in Egypt in a wall painting in the tomb of Nakht, Theban necropolis, New Kingdom, 1425-1405 BC. Arched, it first appears without a column. Its small number of strings is variable. Still in use in Africa, the bowed harp has undergone many evolutions and improvements over the centuries, thanks to the many civilizations that have practiced it.

 

The origin of the llanera harp dates back to the Jesuit religious who contributed extensively to the implementation of the harp in religious services, who brought the instrument from Spain, but over the years, it began to be manufactured in this place for the convenience of the musicians. In the first instance, the harp was an instrument used in churches and for private concerts in the houses of the rulers. Thanks to the Jesuits themselves, they decided to teach music to their congregants. The harp spread to the plains areas.

pill.title: Origin of the Bandola
pill.content:
Etymology:

 

The word bandola comes from the Latin pandūra, which in turn comes from the Greek πανδοῦρα 'three-stringed guitar'.

 

Roots:

 

Also called bandola " pin - pón ". It is a plucked chordophone consisting of four strings. This is variety of the archaic four-stringed vihuela or Latin guitar, but in a larger box. It is traditionally used in joropos, passages and llanero airs instead of the current harp, since the classic organology of the llaneros was composed by bandola, cuatro and capachos. According to Carlos Rojas, the bandola llanera is a melodic guitar with four strings, two of which (the third and fourth) are made of metal and the other two of nylon. With a flat back and pear-shaped, traditional models have a short neck or fingerboard with only seven frets; modern versions, while maintaining the short neck design, present, in the manner of the Spanish guitar, frets embedded on an extension of the fingerboard on the soundboard. It is played with plectrum or pajuela, held between the thumb and index finger, combined in some segments of the piece with very percussive plucking of the first string called jalaos, made with the nail of the middle or ring finger and that are a form of response to the bordoneos (melodic songs implemented in the low register). Other common forms of execution are the segundeo (descending rasgueos) and the trapeo (rasgueos asordinados). The new generations of bandolistas also use melodic ornamentations such as the trill (trémolo) sometimes played over the whole group of strings.

 

This type of archaic Hispanic lute, whose history in the llanera region is unfortunately very little documented, was rescued from an almost extinct tradition around the middle of the 20th century and has reached in recent years a remarkable virtuosic development that has led it to become the only melodic guitar in live use in the current joropo. It is a consubstantial instrument of the "recio" style joropo (with an accelerated tempo and great rhythmic vivacity), and is used in the interpretation of "golpe" and "pasaje".

pill.title: Origin of Cuatro
pill.content:
Etymology:

 

The Venezuelan cuatro, or simply cuatro, is a plucked string instrument that has four tuned orders at the rate of: A3, D4, F#4 and B3. Its peculiar tuning is not totally ascending, it is small in size and owes its name to the number of strings it has. It should not be confused with the current Puerto Rican cuatro of five orders and ten metallic strings.

 

Roots:

 

It has very remote origins. Similar instruments appear in Iranian and Cretan engravings in ovoid and square shape. In the year 3.000& B.C., similar instruments are found in Egypt, derived from Chaldean-Assyrian instruments. The Arab lute or thimphle, through the Moorish invasions, arrived in Spain at the beginning of the 16th century with four orders, where it adopted a new shape, less oval and more similar to the current one, in the shape of an "eight". Later, Maestro Salinas -Maestro de capilla of the Catholic Monarchs- added the fifth string and Vicente Espinel -who established the current strophic form of the tenth string- added the sixth string at the beginning of the XVII century (known as bordon or espinela) giving origin to the Guitar. The lute arrived in the Canary Islands, until it became the timple. This would be exported to America and the Caribbean with the Conquest of America, giving rise, many years later, to the versions known today in South America. The Puerto Rican cuatro, however, bears more resemblance to its ancestor the lute than to the timple of the Canary Islands.

 

Also known as the cuatro llanero or traditional cuatro, it is an inseparable part of typical llanera music ensembles, along with the llanera harp (or bandola, as the case may be). It usually has an accompaniment function, although it can also occupy a soloist position, as a concert instrument, in some cases (usually outside the scope of the aforementioned llanera music).

 

It is normally played strumming the strings with the right hand and making the chords with the left hand. The standard tuning does not allow many exits from this scheme, so sometimes it is necessary to change the tuning to reach new melodic possibilities, as in the case of the cuatro soloist.

pill.title: Origin of the Maracas Llaneras
pill.content:
Etymology:

 

The word maraca comes from the Guarani mbaracá.

 

Roots:

 

Traditional maracas

 

They are made from the fruit of the tapara and filled with seeds called capachos. They have their origin in the indigenous tribes mainly of the Orinoco, who used them for ceremonial purposes long before the arrival of the Spaniards, although usually not in pairs. In the Llanos they are used as accompaniment to the harp and the cuatro in joropo ensembles. The player is known as maraquero. Despite the simplicity of the instrument, the maracas llaneras have achieved an impressive technique of syncopations and contratiempos at high speed. In some regions the player also sings.

pill.title: Origin of the Electric Bass
pill.content:
Etymology:


The electric bass is a musical instrument of the Chordophone family similar in appearance and construction to the Electric Guitar, but with a body of larger dimensions, a neck of greater length and scale, and usually four strings tuned to standard Double Bass tuning.

 

Electric Bass in Llanera Music:

 

The Electric Bass in llanera music normally develops with "simple" rhythmic patterns, these patterns are called ritmotipos which is the indefinite constant repetition of musical figures, this rhythmic pattern or ritmotipo are fundamentally constituted to follow the music in the role of accompaniment, functioning rhythmically and harmonically in the joropo. In some cases and when a musical arrangement is established as a group or by the bass player's initiative, the bass can also function melodically in coherence with the main melody, playing a very important role for the musical group.

pill.title: Introduction
pill.content:
The joropo is a musical genre and traditional dance of Colombia and Venezuela.

 

The joropo is part of the ternary music of the colonial Caribbean, being directly related to the Son Jarocho and Son Huasteco of Mexico, the Mejorana of Panama, among others. These musical expressions developed during the colonial period with influences from Baroque music and inter-oceanic trade.

 

Until the middle of the 20th century, and as far as the plains region of Venezuela and the Eastern Plains of Colombia are concerned, the word joropo referred to a social event -almost a fair- lasting from a few hours to a whole week. People from the locality or people coming from various places, generally attracted by commercial exchange, participated in the event, where the central event was the music, the dance and the contrapunteos. The music of the joropo llanero was provided by a basic ensemble composed of harp, maracas and singing. If there was no harp, it was substituted by a bandola or violin.

 

There is also an instrument, although it is on the way to extinction due to lack of players, such as the CIRRAMPLA, which in the time of the violence of the fifties was the only instrument used at night to lull the llaneros to sleep during those difficult times in the Colombian country.

pill.title: Origin of the Cirrampla
pill.content:
Etymology:

 

Instrument that costs of a wooden stick which has a string tied along, and as a sounding board is used the mouth, vibrating the string with the fingers of the hand. Today it can be considered "extinct" from folklore, since no one teaches its execution anymore and it was used only here in Colombia.

 

Roots:

 

The Jesuits begin to teach the Indians to read, write and teach them religion, also to add and something important the Castilian language, among the things that the Jesuits carried there were some instruments for their time as violins, harps triangles, where they teach them to play to the Indians.

 

It is said that it is an adaptation of the violin by the position in which it is interpreted, it was adapted to a single string and its sound box is the mouth of the interpreter, had its heyday at the time of the war of the fifties (50) when at night should not make noise for fear of attacks by the chulabitas, was the instrument of choice in those sleepless nights and lullaby for many who could not sleep.

pill.title: Origin of Furruco
pill.content:
Etymology:

 

"Furro" is inferred to refer to a rustic musical instrument. Besides being known by the name of the title, this instrument is also called "furruco".

 

Roots:

 

The furruco or furro, is a musical instrument composed of a wooden drum and animal hide, in addition to that it has a wooden rod with a waxed tip which when rubbed from top to bottom produces the sound.

 

In any case, how does the Furruco sound?

 

When rubbing this reed with the hands, the vibration is transferred to the drumhead producing a deep sound similar to the roar of an animal. ... Although the function of the furruco in the ensemble is rhythmic accompaniment, the fact that it always resonates the same low note generates a very interesting pedal sound.

 

You may ask, how is the sound of a drum produced?

 

A drum is a percussion instrument with an indeterminate sound, belonging to the family of membranophones according to the Hornbostel-Sachs classification system. ... The sound is obtained by striking the instrument on the drumhead with the hand or with drumsticks. The snare is also usually percussed.

 

How is the furruco made in the following way?

 

The furruco is a membranophone formed by a cylindrical wooden body. It has a single goat leather drumhead on one of its sides which has a waxed reed attached to it. When rubbing this reed with the hands, the vibration is transferred to the drumhead producing a deep sound similar to the roar of an animal.

pill.title: Origin of the Bandolina "Mandolin".
pill.content:
Etymology:

 

The mandolin is a stringed instrument with four double orders of strings. The number and type of mandolin strings has varied over time and place, but today the predominant configuration is that of the Neapolitan mandolin, with four double strings tuned like the violin (G-R-A-E).

 

The mandolin strings are usually plucked with a pick or plectrum, fingers may also be used. The soundboard may be concave or flat.

 

Roots:

 

If you've ever seen a country band playing live, you may have noticed someone playing what looks like a small guitar. That instrument is, in fact, a mandolin. The mandolin is a musical instrument in the lute family. It generally has four courses of double metal strings, for a total of eight strings, which are tuned in unison.

 

Throughout the following millennia, this instrument would be called by many names, before being called the lute. This instrument traveled throughout Europe and the Middle East. In a 14th century painting, a miniature lute is depicted by an angel. This instrument is called the mandola, by the Latins. The Italians, on the other hand, called this instrument the mandolin.

 

When European immigrants began arriving in North America in the 19th century, they brought the mandolin with them. Due to an interest in strange or exotic things, the mandolin became a popular instrument. The mandolin was popular during the 1850s as a novelty that entertained the middle class. In the late 19th century, there was a surge of Italian immigration that further popularized a version of the mandolin. this instrument would remain popular well into the 20th century, and at one point factories were mass producing it.

 

The mandolin in the 1940s

 

By the 1940s, the mandolin, along with the banjo and guitar, had become popular among middle-class youth on college campuses in the American South. During this time, musicians were more experimental in the way they used the instrument.

 

As a result of this experimentation, new styles of playing emerged, some of which were influenced by techniques that are more closely related to the guitar.

 

In the llanera music has been making a comeback since some time ago, with some interpreters and due to its particular sonority.

pill.title: Introduction
pill.content:
The joropo is a musical genre and traditional dance of Colombia and Venezuela.

 

The joropo is part of the ternary music of the colonial Caribbean, being directly related to the Son Jarocho and Son Huasteco of Mexico, the Mejorana of Panama, among others. These musical expressions were developed during the colonial period with influences from Baroque music and inter-oceanic trade.

 

Until the middle of the 20th century, and as far as the plains region of Venezuela and the Eastern Plains of Colombia are concerned, the word joropo referred to a social event -almost a fair- lasting from a few hours to a whole week. People from the locality or people coming from different places, generally attracted by the commercial exchange, participated in the event, where the central event was the music, the dance and the contrapunteos. The music of the joropo llanero was provided by a basic ensemble composed of harp, maracas and singing. If there was no harp, it was substituted by a bandola or violin.

pill.title: Waltz
pill.content:
Description:

 

The waltz of oral tradition, or popular waltz, uses for its execution the typical instruments of each region.

 

The characteristic musical structure of popular waltzes consists of three parts. Although many musicians sign their compositions with their names, most of them have left their creations anonymous.

 

In the popular tradition, the waltz can be found in many dances and folkloric manifestations, such as the joropo and the tamunangue, among others.

 

Sound element:

pill.title: Traditional Passage
pill.content:
Description:

 

It was born in the herds, thanks to the vaquerías (rodeos of several herds, to separate cattle according to the mark of the ear, since there was no barbed wire or fenced paddocks).

 

The best storytellers or case tellers of the participating herdsmen would gather together, and they would begin by saying: "I am going to tell a story that happened to me or to the master of palo negro, etc.".

 

It was considered that the one who best told the passages was the one who put suspense and interesting details that attracted the listeners, it is of popular knowledge the exaggerations of the llaneros to relate the stories or passages.

 

From that moment on, corridos appeared with lyrics taken from these passages, and little by little they began to call them 'Pasajes', because their music was soft, with less rhythm than the joropo.

 

This musical style is derived from the joropo. However, its main difference is that the playing time is slower and the accents are more perceptible.

 

In El Pasaje we find a freer musical structure, which allows the performer and composer greater creativity and therefore greater versatility.

 

The Passage is formally developed in two sections or stanzas. During the first stanza, two lines of verse are repeated, and in the second stanza, the two missing lines of verse from the first part are sung.

 

Sound element:

pill.title: Six
pill.content:
Description:

 

This generic designation groups together a series of melodic variants built on the same harmonic relationship, among which we find the Seis por derecho, El Pajarillo, La catira, El seis corrío, La tonada, El pajarillo corrío.

 

Of these, the seis por derecho and the pajarillo are constructed in the rhythmic system known as por derecho, the former being in the major mode and the latter in the minor mode.

 

The pajarillo corrio and the catira, in minor mode (there are versions of the catira in major mode); the tonada is presented in major and minor mode. These last four melodic variants are interpreted in the rhythmic system by corrió.

pill.title: Revolt - Water Dog
pill.content:
Description:

 

This generic designation groups together a series of melodic variants, including the Perro de agua (in major mode) and the revuelta (in minor mode); it is usually found as a codal segment (closing element) in other broader structures (zumba que zumba, chipola, periquera, nuevo callao).

 

Sound element:

 

Water dog

pill.title: Chipola
pill.content:
Description:

 

A strong blow that dates back to the 20th century. It is said that it is an inspiration of a man "cabuco" descendant of the Sálivas Indians and that its name corresponds to a way of cutting the hair used by the natives of this ethnic group; and the way "the whites" (¿carapálidas) used to fix the mares' tails.

 

Besides constituting a fundamental rhythm-metric system (accentual regime) of the joropo, the chipola expresses a substantial harmonic relationship in the tonal harmonic management: the authentic cadence.

 

As a musical piece, it is usual that the chipola is presented articulated to the revuelta (as a closing element) and that the structural scheme is implemented consecutively over several degrees of the tonality: I, Vim, V and IIm.

 

Sound element:

pill.title: Six Number
pill.content:
Description:

 

This structure is present in both the por derecho and por corrío systems (the latter is known in Casanare as garipola, major mode) as well as in the major and minor modes. In some regions it is known as seis por numeración, or simply numerao. This style features the use of the dominant auxiliary IV degree.

 

Sound element:

pill.title: Guacharaca
pill.content:
Description:

 

There is no knowledge of its creator; it is known that it is a llanero hit inspired in the 20th century, possibly in the decade of 1910-20 and its name is the same of a precious species of wild llanero turkey the "GUACHARACA".

 

Sound element:

 

Mayor

pill.title: Guacharaca
pill.content: Minor, Known in Casanare as "PATO".

pill.title: Periquera
pill.content:
Description:

 

The periquera is a joropo hit in a major key. In the plains the term periquera also means heated discussion, quarrel or fight. It has been pointed out that after the battle of La Periquera the army of Paez celebrated with a joropo and because of this La Periquera is a type of joropo used especially for the accompaniment of the contrapunteo and can be performed between two or more singers improvising couplets on a certain theme or argument that is often used for the contrapunteo.

 

The name of the "golpe" may be due to a jocular correlation established by the llaneros between the song of the wild parakeets and the song of the "golpe", characterized by a high-pitched voice and a rapid syllabic phrasing.

 

Regarding the origin of the name, other opinions point out that this blow, which they say was Bolivar's favorite and that Paez executed it very well, was an air dedicated to Periquera, a hamlet located on the right bank of the Sarare River from which the current Guasdualito was constituted. It is also said that the village took its name from the hustle and bustle of parrots, macaws and parakeets, which abounded on the banks of the river.

 

Also known as Juana Guerrero and Mocho Hernández, due to some texts sung about this piece.

 

Sound element:

pill.title: Zumba that Zumba
pill.content:
Description:

 

Similar structure to the periquera, developed in a minor mode. Zumbador, Sampablera or simply Zumba, are some other denominations of this piece.

 

Sound element:

pill.title: Nuevo Callao
pill.content:
Description:

 

This structure features the use of the dominant auxiliary II degree, a function that replaces the IV degree of its parent structure, the periquaver. Notice the codal character of the revuelta structure that corresponds to the last four measures of this style.

 

Sound element:

pill.title: San Rafael
pill.content:
Description:

 

San Rafael is the saint of the fishermen and patron saint of several llanero towns. In the songs sung, he is often portrayed as just another "llanero".

 

This hit enjoys great popularity. is in minor mode like most of the llanero hits, is in metric 6x8 and uses as instrumentation harp or bandola llanera, four and maracas".

 

Sound element:

pill.title: San Rafaelito
pill.content:
Description:

 

Similar structure to that of San Rafael, but developed this one in a major key. Also popularly known as HIJO DE SAN RAFAEL.

 

Sound element:

pill.title: Carnival
pill.content:
Description:

 

This rhythm is taken from the same term carnival (comparsa, rejoicing, revelry).
This structure contains in its second part tonal separations to the V and VI degrees, with the use of their auxiliary dominants.

 

Sound element:

pill.title: Quirpa
pill.content:
Description:

 

La Quirpa was born in the middle of the XIX century when the revolutions of the country, such as the Federal War, the Revolution of Azul or the War of 92 ceased a little, where the merchants took advantage of the time, to move through the difficult roads that came or went, from the eastern or central plains to sell their goods and to market livestock.

 

One of these merchants was José Antonio Oquendo, who was nicknamed "QUIRPA", a "llanero de a caballo", a good cattleman with a rope in his hand and on foot, a strong singer of the savannah, a good "coplero", a good "contrapunteador", his voice was recognized in every town and in the most remote corners of the immensity of the plains. His place of origin is not known with certainty, some say that he was from Apurito, Palmarito or Guasdualito, what is certain is that he was a son of the immense land of the plains.

 

Sound element:

pill.title: The Hearts
pill.content:
Description:

 

Cacho or Cacho Pelao Blow

 

This rhythm uses (I and V) degrees in major key and then changes its tonal center to its (VI) minor degree with its respective dominant (VIm, V7 -VIm). It is occasionally used for contrapunteo, where the first coplero rhymes in a major key and the second coplero responds in a minor key. This rhythm is played in the por corrido system.

 

Sound element:

pill.title: Los Mamonales
pill.content:
Description:

 

In its second segment this structure presents tonal separations to VI, V and II degrees with the use of their respective auxiliary dominants.

 

Sound element:

pill.title: Quitapesares
pill.content:
Description:

 

The Quitapesares is a formal variety of the beats that make up the repertoire of the Joropo llanero and along with most of them, dates from the nineteenth century.

 

Unlike most of the other hits, whose authorship is unknown or at least not proven, it is known with precision that the Quitapesares was composed by Carlos Bonnet, Venezuelan composer and conductor.

 

The original concept of the hit has undergone a modification in its chords, so today we have two important versions that are popularly identified as Quitapesares Viejo or Quitapesares Nuevo.

 

With very cheerful chords, this "golpe" is built in 6x8 meter and is traditionally played with harp or bandola llanera, cuatro and maracas.

 

Sound element:

pill.title: The Three Ladies
pill.content:
Description:

 

Structure characterized by the use of the descending scale of chords on the minor mode (its base tonality) and with tonal separation to the relative major (bIII).

 

Sound element:

pill.title: The Sparrowhawk
pill.content:
Description:

 

The Gavilan is a joropo hit dedicated to a bird of the plain called falconiforme of the falconidae family that measures between 30 and 40 cm the male and a little bigger the female, its wings are short rounded and long tail, attacks all kinds of birds including those that are larger than him.

 

This joropo recio is often used in contrapunteo or porfia singing.

 

Its meter is 3x4 of major mode and its literary form is the romance. It has two musical periods, two preceding verses in the major mode and in the relative minor mode the two consequent verses of the couplet.

 

Sound element:

pill.title: The Merecures
pill.content:
Description:

 

Los Merecures This is a strong rhythm. For Colombia it is known that it was composed by Mr. Pedro Francisco Vivas, a musician from Casanare, between 1900 and 1910. This rhythm is one of the oldest rhythms according to oral tradition, and is better known in its instrumental form than with lyrics. The harmonic structure of this rhythm is divided into two parts A and B, and is played in a por corrido system. Part A uses the degrees (I, I, I, I, I, I, V7, V7, V7, V7, V7), and part B (V7/IV, IV, I, I, V7, I).

 

Sound element:

pill.title: The Diamonds
pill.content:
Description:

 

The Diamonds This stroke is located in a major key using (I and V).

 

degree and its resolution is given, in a descending way using all the chords of the scale: (I, VIIº, V7. VIm, VIm, VIm, V7-V, V, V7-IV, IV, V7-IIIm, IIIm, V7-II, IIm, V7, I). The particularity of the harmony of this stroke, is that it uses the dominants of secondaries from the VIm to the IIm degree. This rhythm is found in the por corrido system.

 

Sound element:

posts.title: Joropo Dance
posts.description: To know the styles of the joropo dance.

pill.title: Contents
pill.content:
1. Joropo Dance
    1.1. Aspects of the Joropo Dance
    1.2. The main steps of the joropo
    1.3. Traditional or Creole style
    1.4. Modern or show style

pill.title: Introduction
pill.content: The joropo dance is a cultural representation of our land. Do you know how to dance joropo? Watch the following video and practice the basic steps of the joropo.

pill.title: Joropo Dancing
pill.content: The dance of the joropo is characterized for being of a couple holding each other, where the man holds the woman by both hands. In its theme, the dance shows the dominion of the man over the woman and over nature in general, he is the one who takes the initiative, who stands out, who determines the figures to perform, the woman is limited to observe the movements that he makes every day and to follow him with skill in all the figures that he wants to execute.

pill.title: Joropo Dancing
pill.content:
What you should know about the Joropo Llanero.

 

  • Linked couple dance.
  • The woman holds the man with both hands.
  • The man is the leader in this dance. (figures, movements).
  • The woman follows in the footsteps of the man.
  • There are two positions: punta de soga and the waltz position.
  • When the man stomps, the woman brooms.
  • The man only stomps his feet when there is a peal on the harp or bandola.
  • Generally imitates the sound produced by the horse when galloping

pill.title: Main joropo steps
pill.content:
The main steps of the joropo are the valsiao, the escobillao and the zapatiao.

 

  • The waltz: at the beginning of the dance, the couples embrace each other gently and walk around the dance space in three waltz beats, moving in quick turns in spins to the beat of the music.
  • The escobillao: is the next step, the dancers from the front move their feet in a short back and forth motion as if they were brushing the floor.
  • The zapatiao: is the last step, it is performed by couples without letting go of the embrace, the man makes his footsteps sound and the woman responds with the steps of the escobillao.

gallery.title: Simple waltz of the joropo dance
Introduction to zapateo and escobillado, traditional joropo

pill.title: Traditional or Creole Style
pill.content:
This joropo was born in the "parrando llaneros", it is of a loving character being a fundamental and notorious axis in all the interpretation of the dance.

 

The rational or Creole style is danced soft, slow, balseado and figures that represent the work of plain and zapateos that resemble the gallop of a horse. The zapateo is slow and is not finished off as in the stylized joropo or better known as show joropo.

 

As for the MARKING OF THE STEP: Both men and women mark it with two feet in front and a drag behind, but as a principle the feet should be kept dragging the floor, plus the man can finish off with both legs depending on the musical line and the time where the cut.

 

BASIC FIGURES: It is danced with basic figures, referring to the figures that come from tradition and the work of the plain as: pechicola, zaranda, botalón, rope, half moons, picurera, among many others.

gallery.title: traditional joropo dancer and his granddaughter

pill.title: Modern show style
pill.content:
This joropo was born in the dance academies, used for shows and different types of events in the region. It also has a loving character, but unlike the criollo, in this style it loses the eye contact and love for looking for more speed and showiness.

 

It is a stronger and more elaborate dance, characterized by the complexity of many figures, turns and speed. Likewise, the footwork is stronger as well as the finishing touches. It is a display of tenacity and interpretative endurance that is emphasized in its spectacular precision movements.

 

As for the MARKING OF THE STEP: Both men and women mark it with a foot forward, foot back and dragging, the principle of keeping the feet glued to the floor is lost, allowing them to be elevated giving more speed. It is believed that the man's finish should be done with his leg left always, being also a high shot.

 

BASIC FIGURES: Although it is the basis of the basic figures, but are transformed and are created now called turns making combinations with turns of salsa, merengue or other Latin rhythms, this to generate more striking and more speed.

pill.title: Curiosities
pill.content:
Did you know that...

 

The joropo symbolizes the subtle flirting of the woman and the gallantry and chivalry of the llanero man.

question.question: There are two styles of joropo dancing, the traditional or criollo style and the academic or show style.

posts.title: Joropo dance costumes
posts.description: To know the typical costumes of the joropo dance and their difference.

pill.title: Contents
pill.content:
1. Joropo dance
    1.1. Aspects of the joropo dance costume
    1.2. Traditional or Creole costume
    1.3. Modern costume or show
    1.4. The typical costume hat

pill.title: Introduction
pill.content: The different cultural elements that cover a community are made up of a diversity of symbols that include: food, music, rituals, political organization, values, clothing, among others. The latter has been present since the beginning of human life. From the use of animal skins to protect against climatic conditions, to the development of industries, technologies and a textile and fashion market. Clothing has become a relevant element in the course of life.

pill.title: Joropo Dance Costume Aspects
pill.content: The dance The llanero garment is not exempt from this. Because of the climate, the llanero attire has been molded according to the demands present in the environment. The freshness, humidity and warm climates of the Colombian plains allow the body to be exhibited in a particular way, which allowed the llanero dress to be drawn with a simplicity and functionality that, as mentioned above, has been affected by the climate and the practices of the llanero work.

pill.title: Joropo Dance Costume Aspects
pill.content: The passing of time brought with it the use of dress beyond work, the conditioning of the plains and the extensive arrival of cattle in the middle of the 18th century. The plains territories began to feel the growth of their municipalities and, with it, the incorporation of dresses from other cultures that today have totally permeated the use of dress in the plains. As mentioned, the dress used in the region developed from work practices, the conditioning of the environment and cultural practices such as religious celebrations, festive, family and community events.

pill.title: Traditional or Creole Costume
pill.content:
In the Joropo criollo the woman wears the typical costume which is composed of:

 

  • Hand painted flower skirt with llanero landscapes or flowers.
  • White or flowered sleeveless blouse with tray neck.
  • On the head they wear combs or a cayenne, a typical flower of the plains.
  • They wear almost no accessories or make-up.
  • As footwear they generally wear espadrilles or in many cases they dance barefoot.

 

In the Joropo criollo the man wears two suits.

 

  • The Liki Liki consists of long trousers and long-sleeved shirt with high collar and buttons and white or black hat, which is more elegant.
  • The traditional working man's dress, white or black trousers rolled up halfway down the leg, long-sleeved white shirt, espadrilles or barefoot, hat, better known as the sombrero pelo e guama.

pill.title: Modern costume or show
pill.content:
In women we can find a round dress, one-piece, with tray neck or turtle neck. In the same way that stamped with flowers, hand painted, with rhinestones and different colors.

 

It should be mentioned that the choice is up to the woman and the attention they want to draw. Here they can wear accessories and makeup. They also wear their headdress with respect to the dress. The woman's jewelry matches her wardrobe.

 

For men we find the famous liqui liqui, which is an elegant suit (here the trousers and shirt are not rolled up). It is accompanied by a hat, preferably the hair and guama. As for the espadrilles, they are usually made of leather and with a buckle.

 

The academic costume is the opposite of the traditional costume as its name indicates, it is for shows and its characteristics are: high and bright dresses, strong colors, tight to the body and bright decorations with a bouquet of flowers. The academic costume when it is for competition does not carry shields or symbols of academies, does not wear shiny buttons.

pill.title: The typical costume hat.
pill.content:
The eastern plains through the time have been used hats of all sizes of wings and cups and of all material and form. The hat that has predominated is the one with wide brims and heavy material, such as beaver pelueguama and felt. The hat must be a little heavy so that it does not fall down pushed by the breeze or by the jumps of the horse.

 

The pride of the "llanero" is to want to wear a good hat, it is said that you can get the "llanero" by the hat, there are those who adorn it with embroidery that hang on the neck, others with heron or duck feathers and there are those who put ribbons in the "coleo" parties.

 

The "Pelo e'Guama" hat is a hat commonly used in the plains region of Venezuela. It is a wide brimmed hat, and a bit heavy so that it does not fall off easily when riding, made of rabbit or beaver fur felt. The first ones used in Venezuela were made in Italy (the best known brand was "Borsalino"), and it was so called because of its resemblance to the hair that covers the Guamo fruit (guama), with a chamois-like felt appearance.

pill.title: The typical costume hat.
pill.content:
It is an indispensable part of the typical Venezuelan costume, along with the liqui liqui and the espadrilles. It is still worn on the plains and is a symbol of status and formality. But not all "llaneros" can afford to wear a "Pelo e' Guama" hat.

 

The Cogollo hat is a more economical version of the Sombrero Pelo e' Guama, also with a wide brim, but made with palm heart fibre. It is also used to protect from the sun when working in the fields, and when riding horses. Another variant, the Margarita hat, used in the East of the country, has a round shape.

question.question: The Joropo dance costume is the representative attire of:

pill.title: Curiosities
pill.content:
Did you know...

 

The joropo has Spanish descent, not only in its music but also in its llanero costumes. This musical style originated from the cultural mix that took place in the Venezuelan territory during the conquest.

 

Since then, and mainly since the sixteenth century, it has had deep roots in this country, and thanks to this trajectory (besides being interpreted in almost all its regions), it has become the most distinctive musical genre of this land, being considered since 2014 a Cultural Heritage of the Nation.

posts.title: Llano's work routine
posts.description: To know the origin and activities of plain work.

pill.title: Contents
pill.content:
1. Origin of plain work.
2. Plain work: between customs and trades.
3. Plain work activities.
    3.1. Organization of riders.
    3.2. Preparation of horses, collection and confinement of livestock.
    3.3. Livestock care.
    3.4. Faena llanera.
4. Plain work; tradition made sport.

pill.title: Introduction
pill.content:
The Colombian Orinoquia has developed an understanding of the territory associated with cattle ranching, the work of the plains, the cowboys, the large farms and haciendas, or, as they are called in this territory, the estates and herds, since colonial times. Also, this imaginary alludes to the trades that this task demands and to vast extensions of savannahs, flat land or highlands. The imaginary has also been constructed in relation to a territory far from the cities and associated with great difficulties of access, to gigantic extensions of wastelands and to all sorts of mestizo cultural practices where the joropo, dance, song and a strong oral culture are some of the most representative characteristics.

 

The expansion and flourishing of cattle ranching in the Colombian Orinoquia since the 17th century was possible, in large part, thanks to the possibility of bringing large livestock productions to the areas of consumption by means of a network of cattle trails. "During the New Granada, while large herds were established on the Atlantic coast, Tolima and the Magdalena plains, livestock, roads and meat consumption defined the economic vocation of the Eastern Plains".

 

The work of the cowboys who dedicated their lives to this work and to the development of this trade was also essential. Since then, the roads that were opened or that, being indigenous roads in pre-colonial times, were adapted for the herding of cattle have been fundamental, thus connecting the different estates and herds with nearby populations, as the practice of cattle ranching grew and techniques were developed to adapt, guarantee survival and transform the environment. "In rural societies, the road networks that connect the territory continue to be used frequently despite the development of roads. Roads, despite their progressive abandonment, articulate social relations, practices and meanings". Colombia owes much of its development, communication, and construction of its nation territory to the trade of muleteering, cowherding, mules, horses, cattle trails, mule trails, and roadside inns.

pill.title: Origin of the plain work
pill.content:
There is reference to something similar to "plain work" towards the end of the 16th century; that is, only a century after the Spaniards had arrived in America, this activity was already foreshadowed. It seems that the work of the plains (domestication and management of cattle) has to do with a need that is more related to the demands of the environment and a wild context that demanded the development of techniques to domesticate both maroon cattle and horses and the development of knowledge of nature and various technologies, than to a simple inheritance or learning of a model derived from the Jesuit herds, as many cowboys state in their stories.

 

Before there was the concept of ownership of land, there was the concept of ownership of cattle and, based on the ownership of rodeos or the number of head of cattle, the common right of use was granted or claimed, and later (when fences were built), on the possession of the land. This was given in the beginning by customary laws that were consolidated through something socially accepted by the ranchers or owners, which became the maximum expression of the repressive colonial legislation around the year 1811, sanctioned as "the laws or ordinances of the plain" in the state of Guárico and that later would extend throughout the entire Colombian-Venezuelan Orinoquia. The laws or ordinances of the plains were then implemented in different places of this territory since the beginning of the 19th century, but they had already been prepared for more than a century by the Jesuit herdsmen, who carried out a powerful pedagogical work and prepared the minds of the Creoles and mestizos since the end of the 17th century. Through these laws it was established, among other things, that the ownership of land would eventually be granted only to those who had cattle and in an amount corresponding to the size of their herd; in this way, as we see today, the richest were entitled to more land. With the passage of time, this generated social problems that increased until they degenerated into problems of violence and cattle rustling (cattle theft). From the second half of the 18th century, the laws or ordinances of the plains gave the Venezuelan Creole aristocracy the power (this is where the establishment of order began) to "arrest, prosecute and condemn mestizos or pardos" who committed any crime, giving priority to cattle rustling as one of the main crimes.

 

This establishment of "order" also determined the way in which cattle were branded and the way in which the concept of cattle ownership was managed, as well as the documentation required for the purchase and sale of cattle, horses and other animals that were bred and traded. With the growth of herds and the increase of large landowners, unbranded cattle were especially appropriated by the peones or workers of the plains. This fact, in a way, was protected by the concept of ownership, which said that if the cattle had no brand then it had no owner, and not grazing on land of defined ownership (because there were not yet fences for the savannahs), then it was recognized as a maroon cattle. This problem worsened significantly and was one of the main causes of the drastic application of the mentioned "Ordinances or Laws of the plains".

 

From the care and possession of livestock, the territory was also conceived from the process of conquest and colonization, determining a landscape that was slowly transformed into prairies suitable for livestock, as well as the development of techniques for the use and manufacture of objects, adaptation of spaces and a whole cultural world determined especially by and for livestock. In some parts of the Orinoquia, the implementation of the laws of the plains took place late, however, these were executed as something common at the time of settling differences between ranchers and owners of estates or herds and it is evident from the oral tradition of the cowboys.

 

It is noteworthy that these laws regulated almost exclusively the livestock, horses, pigs, distribution of land and estates in the plains. This shows that from the beginning the establishment of order and control was governed from the livestock production and livestock, in addition to the mere food. Early on, before the 19th century, many of the laws of the plains were being applied. It is worth mentioning that in some parts of Venezuela these laws were officially enacted in the mid-twentieth century, but within the oral culture of the cowboys it is recognized, through their stories, that Simon Bolivar came to sign the laws of the plains a few years before his death in 1830. These laws were also born out of the lack of state presence in these remote places, and for many fathers and grandfathers of the cowboys who participated in this research work, it was a source of pride and honor to comply with them and enforce them. This form of social and territorial order allows us to begin to understand the context in which the culture of the cowboys or plains workers is structured and formed, at first. Determining certain practices related to the trade of cowherding, the ways of relating to each other and other social aspects that have to do with the ways of applying justice and / or punishments for those who broke the rules. This context of isolation from the technologies of the State led these societies to generate this type of agreements to avoid and solve conflicts. These agreements were materialized, among others, in: the marks in the ears, the irons in the skin of the cattle, characteristics of the way in which the extensive cattle ranching is developed, and in general in all this productive sociocultural model that gives origin to the songs of plain work and to all its associated culture.

pill.title: Flat work activities
pill.content:
Organization of riders

 

The "Culatero" is the rider in charge of herding the cattle, a different task from the "cabrestero", since he is in charge of guiding the cattle to their destination. The "Culatero" has the job of not letting any of the cattle leave the herd. The Orejeros: their job is to keep an eye on the sides of the herd; they will not allow the cattle to leave the group, but they are in charge of the order on both sides of the herd.

 

For its part the Caballicero as its name suggests, is the one who is responsible solely and exclusively care for the horses used in this demanding work, he will be responsible for driving the horses from the corral to the paddocks to graze, checks that they have no mataduras (name that refers to the peeling on the back of the beasts, caused by sweat and implements) and is aware of bathing them in addition to reviewing the hooves of each of the horses.

 

Finally there is the Chocotero who was in charge of the details such as food, lodging for the riders, etc., in the long journeys that were made when cattle were taken from Arauca to Villavicencio or Cumaral. This figure of the chocotero, many llaneros today do not know it; that is why, for MinCultura, this fundamental aspect for the work of the llano should be enhanced.

 

"The Chocotero went ahead of the other riders on mules with all the suitcases, he was the one who carried the pots for cooking, for beating the oats... he arrived at the inns in front to ask for permission for the cattle gatherings, for the gatherings of the people in the cattle inns (...) he was in charge of making the food, carrying the suitcases, the pots and pans, the one who made the food and was ahead of the cowboys more or less an hour ahead of the cattle ranch".

 

Now, the job of the cabrestero was to guide and lead all the work on the plain, in fact, he is called cabrestero because he will always be the halter in the herd. According to the RAE (Royal Spanish Academy) it is said that cabestro means: "Tame ox that serves as a guide to the bulls, mainly in a bull run". However, in this case the name is assigned to a person whose experience will be in charge of guiding the livestock along the paths. It should be noted that the name of "cabrestero" is not assigned by mere whim choosing the person at random, this rider must meet at least two requirements, the first is as we said before, to know very well the way, the terrain to travel, and secondly, to know how to sing to guide the herd, in a word, to be an excellent "baquiano".

pill.title: Flat work activities
pill.content:
Preparation of horses, collection and confinement of livestock

 

First check the health of the horses, and saddle them correctly (first put the saddle pad on the horse, then adjust the saddle pad on the head, on top of the saddle pad put the saddle on the left side of the horse, then adjust the rebreech, adjust the breastplate).

 

The work on the plains really starts after the horses are gathered. The cattle are gathered in the savannah, for example, in a herd of 3000 cattle, it would take approximately six rodeos. The cabrestero knows that in a specific part the rodeo that is needed leaves, he goes out and when the specific point arrives, the others spread out to collect the cattle well, the caporal is in charge of organizing the riders in the different points to incorporate the cattle in the stop.

gallery.title: Plainsmen with cattle in the river

pill.title: Flat work activities
pill.content:
Livestock care

 

Livestock management includes a set of actions to ensure animal health (vaccinations, bathing, healthy feeding). These are measures of prevention, control and/or eradication of diseases; prescription and administration of drugs, therapeutic and surgical treatments carried out responsibly and balanced feeding. For this it is necessary to have a sanitary calendar.

 

In addition to the above, the activity of cattle herding (branding the animal) is of great importance to prevent cattle rustling (cattle theft).

pill.title: Faena llanera
pill.content: The Faena de Llano is a demanding work that is done twice a year, with a duration that, according to the size of the herd, can last five or six weeks. The first work takes place between May and June, when the water comes in, and the second between November and December, when the water comes out. The work that the cowboys face allows them to demonstrate their skills and knowledge of the plains, as well as their authenticity that they will show through their work elements and their cultural symbols.

pill.title: Plain work, tradition made sport
pill.content:
The coleo is the sport that was born in the task of branding calves in the corral. Two cowboys pair up: one ropes, while the other person grabs the animal's tail and pulls it down. The one who roped then brings the red-hot iron and marks the calf. This work is called the hierra and takes place every six months, in November and May. Later on, the coleo was extended to the savannah, when the horse is hung from the horse to stop the wild cattle from fleeing from the herd.

 

Later, coleo was taken to the streets of the towns during the patron saint festivities. The bocacalles were fenced with guadua and simple boxes were built, ten or more wild bulls were released and each coleador would try to knock his bull down in front of the box of the woman of his affection. The girls would put colored ribbons on the arms of the coleador who brought them a bull. Finally, they built corrals or arenas three hundred meters long by twelve meters wide and three meters high, with corrals or "cosos" in each corner.

 

The chute is divided into four zones. The preparation zone is counted from the exit of the bullring and is fifty meters long. Whoever knocks down the bull in this zone has the highest score that is given for the award. The following zones of one hundred meters each are destined for coloring and the score for the bullfight decreases as the bull is knocked down in the first one hundred meters or more. The last zone is not for bullfighting and whoever knocks down the bull there is penalized. It is called the dead zone and is fifty meters long.

 

More recently the 'team penning' (apart and confinement of cattle), is a sport that has generated great national recognition in the world of equine training for the cowherd, plain work and other modalities such as coleo. In these sports, American Quarter Horses, American Pinto and in a lesser preference the Appaloosa horse are used. Equine that, for its muscular strength, the compactness of his body, his explosion and speed and intelligence to understand and manipulate livestock, become perfect specimens to develop such sports originating in the culture of plain work and livestock.

 

The sport consists of a team of three riders who must separate three cattle specifically marked with the same number from a batch of cattle of thirty specimens, and take them to a corral without going over an imaginary limit cattle with a different number than the one assigned. To be clear, there are ten groups of three different herds with the same number. But to better understand and visualize this sport and its rules is worth watching this video that demonstrates the great interest that is generating the sport at the National level and especially in Antioquia and the Eastern Plains.

pill.content:
Did you know that...

 

It is an American sport, which has its greatest exponent in the United States through the Team Penning Association of the United States (USTPA). Its main promoters are undoubtedly the associations of horses such as the AQHA (American Quarter Horse Association) and APHA (American Paint Horse Association) main breeds used for this sport. In addition to magazines, ranches and clubs that show that the United States has the best structure and organization for the development of the American Quarter Horse and American Pinto breeds, and in sports directly related to these breeds such as Team Penning.
