posts.title: Biodiversity - Ecosystems
posts.description: This capsule highlights the great variety of ecosystems and biodiversity of the department of Casanare.

pill.title: Contents
pill.content:
1. Biodiversity of Casanare.
2. Ecosystems.
    2.1. Plain.
    2.2. Altillanura.
    2.3. Sel vas.
    2.4. Páramo / Andina.
    2.5. Foothill forest.
    2.6. Sheets

pill.title: Introduction
pill.content:
In our quest to better understand nature, humans use the study of ecosystems as one of the most important functional units and tools that allow us to describe, from an ecological point of view, any corner of the planet. The concept of ecosystem was established by Roy Clapham in 1930, with the aim of having a specific term that would reflect the interrelationships established between communities of living beings and the physical environment that surrounds them.

 

Ecosystems include a whole series of intraspecific (between individuals of the same species) and interspecific (between individuals of different species) interactions, based on the different resources that the ecosystem itself provides to living beings, and the various energy flows that occur in it. In this pill we will go through the concept of ecosystem, types and ecosystems present in the department of Casanare.

pill.title: Biodiversity of Casanare
pill.content: The department of Casanare comprises a diverse territory in ecosystems, due to its high altitudinal variation and the modeling of important watersheds associated with the Meta River. It has a complex of ecosystems with a combination of mountain foothills (10%), foothills (20%) and savannahs (70%), where biodiversity has historically shared the territory with extensive cattle ranching developed by the traditional llaneros, who are currently facing changes in the national development model that includes policies of expansion of the hydrocarbon and industrial agriculture sectors.

gallery.title: Biodiversity on the llanera Casanare route

pill.title: Biodiversity of Casanare
pill.content:
FLORA

 

According to studies carried out in the flora of Casanare, a richness of 1479 species grouped in 659 genera and 146 families is registered. There are 11 subspecies and 19 varieties. The families with the greatest representativeness of genera and species were Rubiaceae and Poaceae and the genera with the greatest number of species were Inga and Miconia.

 

INSECTS

 

The communities of ants and butterflies were studied in three localities of the municipalities of Hato Corozal, Tauramena and Trinidad, with sampling stations in different habitats and altitudinal gradients between 117 and 462 m. We recorded 175 species of butterflies and 89 species of ants grouped in 36 genera and eight subfamilies of the family Formicidae.

 

FISH

 

The hydrographic network of Casanare belongs to the Meta river basin, it was sampled in 2010. It recorded 567 species of fish grouped into 242 genera, 41 families and 10 orders. This richness represents 86% of the 658 species of the Colombian Orinoquia. The orders Characiformes (263 spp.) and Siluriformes (202 spp.), have the largest number of species.

 

AMPHIBIANS

 

Based on recent studies and sampling in four locations in the municipalities of Hato Corozal, Orocué, Tauramena and Trinidad, 49 species of amphibians are recorded for Casanare distributed in two of the three orders of the Amphibia class: frogs and toads (Anura) and caecilians or blind snakes (Apoda). Threatened amphibian species group seven species according to the IUCN (2011) and two according to the Red Book of Amphibians of Colombia.

 

REPTILES

 

The wealth of reptiles of Casanare was 65 species distributed in three orders: turtles (order Testudinata), Cachirres, Babillas, alligators and crocodiles (order Crocodylia) and the squamates (Order Squamata) distributed in three suborders; lizards or saurians (suborder Sauria), snakes or vipers (suborder Ophidia) and tatacoas (suborder Amphisbaenia).

 

BIRDS

 

According to field observations in four municipalities of Casanare - Hato Corozal, Orocué, Tauramena and Trinidad, a richness of 507 species was recorded for Casanare. This record increased by 29 species the list of birds of the Department, documented the expansion of the geographical range of nine Amazonian species and identified habitats and areas for regional, national and international conservation of birds in Casanare.

 

MAMMALS

 

Based on the literature review and samplings carried out in four municipalities of the Department, 200 species grouped in 35 families and 12 orders are registered in Casanare. This richness represents 45% of the Colombian mastofauna. There is a high percentage of small mammals such as rodents, bats and marsupials, and to a lesser extent medium mammals such as primates, mustelids and armadillos, as well as large mammals such as tapirs, chigüiros and felines, of which 16 species have some degree of threat.

pill.title: Ecosystem
pill.content:
An ecosystem is a system formed by a set of organisms, the physical environment in which they live (habitat) and the biotic and abiotic relationships established between them. The species of living beings that inhabit a given ecosystem interact with each other and with the environment.

 

There is a great diversity of ecosystems on the planet. All of them are formed by biotic factors (living beings) and abiotic factors (non-living elements, such as soil or air). There are different types of ecosystems that are classified according to the habitat in which they are located:

 

Aquatic ecosystems: They are characterized by the presence of water as the main component and are the most abundant type of ecosystem. This group includes the ecosystems of the oceans and those of fresh or salty continental waters, such as rivers, lakes and lagoons.

 

Terrestrial ecosystems: They take place on the earth's crust and out of water in different types of relief: mountains, plains, valleys, deserts. Some examples of this type of ecosystems are forests, scrublands, steppe and deserts.

 

Mixed ecosystems: These are ecosystems that are located in areas where different types of terrain "intersect", for example, where aquatic and terrestrial environments are combined. Examples of this type of ecosystems are mangroves, estuaries and coasts.

pill.title: Plain
pill.content:
Constituted by the dragging and deposition of materials coming from the mountain range, several subunits can be distinguished, from the foothills to the Meta River. The plains extend up to 300 m., occupy about 70% of the territory and are home to 40% of the human population. For its description it has been divided into non-floodable high plains and floodable low plains. The former are made up of alluvial plains with a meandering structural control regime. The latter are made up of overflow alluvial plains with a slight aeolian influence; aeolian plains covering an overflow alluvial plain and minor alluvial plains.

 

The alluvial plain, which extends from the end of the piedmont to the limits of the departments of Vichada and Meta, is made up of flooded savannahs, gallery forests on the great rivers Pauto, Cusiana, Casanare, and wind plains in the center and south covered by grasses and forest on the banks of the canals and rivers.

 

There are open habitats made up of wetlands, flooded savannahs and highland savannahs (non-flooded and eolian), where mechanized agriculture is developed with a predominance of rice, extensive and semi-intensive cattle ranching and oil palm plantations. The forested areas are made up of gallery forests, scrublands, morichales and forest plantations.

pill.title: Highlands
pill.content:
The Colombian Orinoquia is bordered to the north by the State of Apure, on the southwestern border of Venezuela; to the south, by the Guaviare River; to the west, by the eastern mountain range; and to the east, by the Orinoco River. Geographically, the eastern plains belong to the Orinoco River basin, which contains three land systems or landscapes: the piedmont, the alluvial plains and the highlands.

 

The Altillanura is the name given to the non-floodable zone of the Eastern Plains, as these savannas are higher than the Meta riverbed. They are not flooded in the same way as the lands on the north side of the river, where Casanare is located. The savannas make up the municipalities of Puerto López, Puerto Gaitán and Mapiripán in Meta, and the municipalities of La Primavera, Cumaribo, Puerto Carreño and Santa Rosalía in Vichada.

 

The altillanura is a type of formation where, due to its topographic position and edaphic evolution, the processes of flooding and generation of wetlands of the "swamp" type do not occur. Thus, what drainage restrictions generate in the floodplain, in the altillanura are replaced by wind erosion processes or surface sediment dragging in rainfall events, which transport the material to the streams that dissect its surface.

 

The Colombian Orinoco region should be the main bet for the large-scale exploitation of the expanded agricultural frontier, consisting of 13.5 million hectares located in the departments of Arauca, Casanare, Meta, Vichada, Guaviare and Guainía. Of this total, about 2.8 million hectares have proven agricultural and forestry potential.

gallery.title: From the "Cerrado" to the "savannah" and the "altillanura"

pill.title: Jungles
pill.content:
Little is known about the ecology of the tropical rainforests of the piedmont; in general, they are characterized by a continuous and heterogeneous canopy due to the steep slope and irregular terrain with predominantly clayey soils in the interfluves and sandy soils on the slopes. The vertical structure of the forest is multi-layered with trees that reach up to 30 m in height and although there is an abundance of the milk tree, the higuerón or matapalos and the tronador that produces a caustic and toxic milk, the dominant species are the leguminous plants such as the dormilón or orejero. There are also valuable woods such as the laurel oloroso, the cabo de hacha or costillo, the achapo and the peinemono; among the fruit trees are the sapote, the mamey and the caimos.

 

This strip is rich in palms with enormous stilt roots - more than 20 species - such as the palmiche, the mil pesos, the zancona and the choapos, which sometimes emerge above the canopy. In the lower strata stand out for their large leaves several species of Cyclanthaceae such as the iraca, whose leaves similar to those of the palm are used for making hats and several species of Heliconia such as the platanillos; the high humidity of this area favors the development of many epiphytic plants among which the ferns stand out.

 

Flooded forests

 

Some of the last remnants of the flood forests are found in the overflow plains of the Meta, Cusiana, Pauto and Casanare rivers, on a landscape enriched by alluvial sediments of Andean origin, deposited during the last floods. The fluvial dynamics have modeled a complex of geoforms in the overflow plain, such as natural dikes or accumulations of coarse materials on the sides of the riverbeds, wide depressions -basins- between the dikes of one river and the other, and abandoned riverbeds that form lagoons or madreviejas. The fluvial landscape is very dynamic and changes during each flood or drought phase, generating a mosaic of environments for vegetation and fauna and determining the types of land use and the use of biotic resources.

pill.title: Paramo - Andina
pill.content: They are extensive cold and humid treeless regions that crown the mountain ranges above the Andean forest, have abrupt climatic changes and are almost always covered by fog. The predominant grassland is dominated by grasses interspersed with shrubs and with cespitose, cushion and arroset plants, especially the caulirrósulas of the genus Espeletia of 1 to 4 m. high. The páramo is delimited by the differences in the bioclimatic floors and was defined by an elevation higher than 3100 m. It consists of grassland formations of fasciculate grasses (Calamagrostis and Festuca) and caulirrosuletum (Espeletia spp.), as well as other species that include bushes and saplings of 1 to 5 m., Diplostephium revolutum, Gynoxys paramuna, Miconia summa, Polylepis boyacensis, Senecio caviniodes and Valeriana arborea.

pill.title: Paramo - Andina
pill.content:
Páramo de Pisba

 

The Park is located in a strategic biogeographic zone and is a great water star that provides environmental goods and services to more than 30,000 inhabitants of the departments of Boyacá and Casanare, particularly represented in the water production of the Cravo Sur, Pauto, Tocaría, Pisba, Arzobispo rivers and the Guaza, Corral Piedra and El Tuque streams. Tocaría, Pisba, Arzobispo and the Guaza, Corral de Piedra and El Tuque streams. In the Eastern Cordillera, in the department of Boyacá, municipalities of Soacha, Socotá, Tasco and Mongua.

 

In the northeastern part it extends its connectivity with El Cocuy National Natural Park, through the Pisba - Cocuy biological corridor. Within the area of the Pisba National Natural Park, the sub-Andean forest, the Andean forest, the high Andean forest, the sub-páramo and the páramo itself are represented.

 

As for the fauna, the white-tailed deer and red or soche deer, the fara, the rabbit and the tinajo stand out. The deer, the ocelot, the puma and the spectacled bear are subjected to great pressures due to hunting and loss of habitat. Its multiple lagoons are a place of confluence of a great diversity of aquatic birds.

 

From the environmental point of view this park is very important because it connects with the Cocuy to form a biological corridor. In addition, several rivers are born here and there are many pristine water lagoons. From the historical point of view, Pisba is relevant for having been the passage of the liberation troops to the interior of the country.

pill.title: Foothill forest
pill.content:
Known as piedmont hill forests or hygrophilous forests of the piedmont of the plains or piedmont forests of the Cordillera, they are forests without intervention on sites with slopes between 25 and 50% inclination, distinguished by species such as Guarea cf. macrocarpa, Cedrela montana, Ficus glabrata, Luehea seemannii, Persea sp. and Eugenia sp.

 

Located between 300 and 1100 m., they are characterized for the region of Arauca and Casanare by high and dense forests with heights that oscillate between 20 to 25 m. in alluvial fans of the piedmont, characterized by the predominance of Cedrela odorata, Cordia sp, Crepidospermum sp., Inga spp., Mabea cf. occidentalis, Ocotea sp., Pourouma sp., Pouteria sp., Protium sp., Rollinia edulis, Tabebuiar cf. rosea, Tapirira guianensis, Trichilia cf. pallida, Virola sp. and Warscewiczia coccínea.

pill.title: Sheets
pill.content:
Non-floodable savannas

 

Known and described by many authors as savannas, they are a plant community of varied physiognomy along its extension, constituted by herbaceous plants that form an ecologically dominant stratum in spite of the eventual presence of woody elements.

 

Floodable savannas can be distinguished from non-floodable savannas. The latter include open, non-floodable savannah, open grassy savannah, wooded savannah, wooded savannah with palms, non-floodable shrub savannah and shrub savannah and chaparral.

 

This unit, called piedmont savannahs, is very transformed and the water conditions do not determine its presence, dominated by species of grasses, cyperaceae, leguminous and composite polygalaceae: Hyptis conferta, Mesosetum rottboellioides, Panicum micranthum, Paspalum pulchelum, P. nudatum, Rhynchospora longispicata, R. basbata and Trachypogon plumosus. Among the trees, Byrsonima crassifolia, Byrsonima sp., Bowdichia virgilioides, Curatella americana, Palicourea rigida, Roupala complicata and Xylopia sp.

 

Flooded savannahs

 

Classified as hyper-seasonal savannas, their climatic conditions and water stress give them particular characteristics. In this category we group different types of savannahs such as open flooded savannah with sparse and low herbaceous and dense grassy strata, flooded during most of the year with 30-100 cm. of water and presence of palm groves; open seasonally flooded savannah with total absence of woody elements. In addition to the Savannah of banks, lowlands and estuaries defined according to the type of flooding as follows: a) the bank or high place not floodable in the rainy season; b) the low or lowland, part of the savannah that is flooded in the rainy season and c) the estuary that is deeply flooded in the rainy months.

question.question: How are ecosystems classified according to the habitat in which they are located?

pill.title: Curiosities
pill.content:
Did you know that...

 

Casanare is one of the largest departments in the country and with large hydrographic slopes that descend from lush moorlands and water reserves. Territory from which the independence of Colombia and the consolidation of the liberation campaign of the then New Granada took place.

 

With an area of more than 44,000 square kilometers and a population of more than 325,000 inhabitants, the department is divided into 19 municipalities, including its capital, Yopal, which was founded in the early twentieth century as a result of migration in the vast plains.

 

The territory of Casanare is composed of three physiographic groups: the eastern slope of the eastern mountain range, a mountainous part with areas with peaks of up to 4,000 meters above sea level; the foothills, with some hills, but mostly undulating relief with extensive grasslands; and finally, the alluvial plain, configured with flooded savannas and forest on the banks of different rivers.

pill.title: Introduction
pill.content: Casanare has a great natural wealth and among it stands out the fauna, where we find diversity of birds, mammals, reptiles, fish and amphibians that give color and joy to the llanero landscapes; they also teach us their natural wealth through songs, courtship dances, care of their offspring and above all their role in the balance of nature. I invite you to learn about the importance of the Casanarean fauna in the preservation of ecosystems and as part of our llanero culture.

gallery.title: Casanare the heart of the plains

pill.title: Animals
pill.content: For thousands of years, humans have taken advantage of various species of animals for their own benefit, being cattle, horses and pack animals, essential in carrying out daily tasks. The work of the plains is an example of this, where the "llaneros" from very early in the morning begin their work of "vaquería" and that in recent times has become a tourist attraction, where visitors accompany the "llanero" and perform with him, this noble work.

pill.title: Animals
pill.content:
Horse

 

The scientific name of the horse is Equus ferus caballus, are known to mankind since ancient times, where they were initially domesticated and essential as a means of transport and other work in many cultures, are perissodactyl mammals (toes ending in hooves) whose embryonic development is about 11 months and the female has only one offspring per birth.

 

There are approximately 400 breeds of horses that specialize in different types of tasks; for example, in the llanero culture horses are fundamental, since they are strong, noble and resistant animals for the arduous work under the sun, the water, and the work of cowherding, being the faithful companion of the llanero in his day to day.

pill.title: Animals
pill.content:
Cattle

 

Cattle have a diversity of breeds, whose differences lie in their place of origin, physical characteristics and meat yield. In Colombia, due to its richness of territories, we can find cattle for meat production, dairy production or dual purpose depending on the breed and breeding intention.

 

In the plains of Casanare the most representative breeds are Gyr and Brahman, whose main purpose is dairy and meat production. We also find our own breed, the Creole Casanare, which unfortunately still does not have sufficient studies of its potential and is on the verge of disappearing due to successive crossbreeding.

pill.title: Animals
pill.content:
Beasts or mules

 

Mules are hybrids resulting from a cross between a donkey (male) and a mare (female horse) or the case of the hinnies, which are also mules, but come from a cross between a horse (male) and a female donkey.

 

Among their characteristics we find that most of them are sterile, they can be males or females and their physical appearance is very similar to that of a horse; they are animals of great physical strength and resistance to disease, for this reason they are ideal as an aid in the work of the plainsman.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content: Colombia is a megadiverse and privileged country due to its geographical location, which allows us to find a variety of climates conducive to the diversity of species. The Colombian fauna and especially the Casanareña fauna shows us multiple forms, adaptations to the environment, wonderful behaviors, genetic and natural wealth; among the most outstanding we have the chigüiros, toninas, otters, macaws, tapirs, jaguar, guacharacas, gabanes, coteras and cachicamo among others.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Small and medium-sized mammals

 

Chigüiro Hydrochoerus hydrochaeris

 

General characteristics: It is the largest rodent mammal in the world, herbivore with rough fur that varies from yellowish, reddish brown and dark brown, its weight in adulthood can be between 40 to 90 kg, depending on the place and food availability.

 

In Colombia it has several common names, for example, in Meta, Caquetá and Amazonas it is called capibara, the Tikunas in Amazonas call it copiwara and in Arauca and Casanare it is called Bocaeburro, culo pando and chigüire.

 

Habitat and reproduction: They are animals that live in herds, generally associated with bodies of water such as streams, lagoons, mangrove swamps associated with gallery forests, savannahs or grasslands, which gives them protection, food and shelter.

 

Their fertility is high and is associated with the fact that they are rodents and the availability of food; embryonic development lasts approximately 4 months and they have between 2 to 8 offspring per birth. As for parental care, it is present until the offspring are independent.

 

Importance: This species is considered of great ecological value because it acts as a biological controller of the excessive growth of vegetation and is a fundamental part of the trophic chains. At the economic level, it is a species of sustainable use through zoo farms, as long as they have the respective licenses for its operation.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Lapa Cuniculus paca

 

General characteristics: It is a medium-sized rodent mammal, weighs between 7 to 10 kg in adulthood, its fur is brown or orange with rounded white spots. It has many common names depending on the region where it is found, for example, boruga, guagua or paca. They are terrestrial habits, good swimmers and feed mainly on a variety of fruits, seeds, tubers, stems and leaves.

 

Habitat and reproduction: they are found in wooded, humid and mountainous environments, generally associated with bodies of water. Their gestation period varies from 114 to 118 days and generally only one calf is born per birth.

 

Importance: As their feeding habits are mainly frugivorous, they play a very important role in the dispersion of seeds of several types of plants; they also play a fundamental role in the trophic chains as prey for numerous species of carnivores such as the jaguar or the puma among others.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Cajuche Pecari tajacu

 

General characteristics: The cajuche has several common names among which are zaino, peccary or collared peccary. It is an artiodactyl mammal of medium size that lives in herds, grayish to brown fur with a whitish spot in the form of necklace neck; weigh between 20 to 30 kg and have a gland in the dorsal part that secretes a penetrating substance.

 

Habitat and reproduction: This species inhabits gallery forests, jungles and savannas, the latter ecosystem being the least frequent. Its diet consists of fruits, snails, invertebrates, small vertebrates, berries and tubers. The embryonic development lasts between 141 and 151 days approximately and 1 to 4 young are born per birth, which are weaned 3 to 4 months after birth.

 

Importance: They are animals of consumption for several populations in the region that benefit from the sale of their meat and oil, and it is said that their flavor is similar to that of pork, so the llaneros have developed strategies for their management and conservation.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Picure Dasyprocta fuliginosa

 

General characteristics: Another common name for this species is ñeque, it is a rodent mammal characterized by its reddish-brown fur and it can weigh from 2 to 3 kg. Like other mammals it makes burrows that it uses as shelter against possible predators.

 

Habitat and diet: It is found mainly in humid forests and scrublands, feeding on palm fruits, seeds, tubers, some herbs, flowers and insects.

 

Importance: They are animals with the habit of burying seeds as a reserve method for times of food shortage, but sometimes they do not find them again and these germinate into new palms and trees, which makes these rodents seed dispersers.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Saffron milkvetch Dasypus sabanicola

 

General characteristics: Also known as armadillo or cachicamo sabanero, it is a mammal that has little hair, but has an armour composed of 8 to 9 mobile plates that allow it to protect itself from predators; they have strong claws on their extremities that are used to dig their burrows and catch their prey. In adulthood they can weigh from 2 to 4 kg, they have short sight, but a good sense of smell.

 

Habitat and reproduction: It lives in scrublands, forests associated with bodies of water and savannahs. It is omnivorous, feeding on invertebrates, fruits and roots. The gestation period of the offspring is approximately 4 months and a curious fact about the offspring is that 4 males or 4 identical females are born.

 

Importance: It is an important predator of insect populations in the region.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Aquatic mammals

 

Commerson's dolphin Inia geoffrensis

 

General characteristics: They are cetacean mammals also known as pink dolphins, they feed on different types of fish, crabs and small turtles; their longevity is estimated between 30 and 40 years, they can measure approximately 2.8 meters and reach a weight of 180 kg.

 

They are currently on the verge of extinction, so it is essential to preserve them.

 

Habitat and reproduction: Commerson's dolphins inhabit the waters of rivers and lagoons in the Amazon and Orinoquia, their presence being, an indicator of clean waters in the area where they are found. They have a gestation period of 11 to 12 months and a single calf is born, which they take care of for several years.

 

Importance: This species is considered a biological controller of fish species and a regulator of the food chain. For example, it feeds on Caribbean fish that are predators of juveniles of other types of fish of commercial interest to local fishermen.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Manatees Trichechus manatus

 

General characteristics: Manatees are sirenian mammals whose body shape is robust, they have 3 fins, one caudal and two pectoral fins that facilitate their displacement in the water. Their nostrils are special, as they close when they submerge. Its size can vary between 2.5 and 4.5 meters and its weight can reach between 200 and 600 kg.

 

Habitat and diet: This species is found in bog systems, coastal waters, and freshwaters of the tropics and subtropics. They feed mainly on aquatic plants and sometimes also consume fish and invertebrates.

 

Importance: They play the role of nutrient recyclers in the ecosystem they inhabit, which contributes to the proliferation of plant and animal populations.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Large mammals

 

Otter Pteronura brasiliensis and Lontra longicaudis

 

General characteristics: Otters are carnivorous mammals associated with bodies of water. In the department of Casanare we find the giant otter (Pteronura brasiliensis) that can measure 1.5 to 2 meters including the tail, its fur is dark brown and has yellowish spots on the neck that differ from one individual to another; and the neotropical otter (Lontra longicaudis) that measures approximately between 90 cm and 1.40 meters whose fur is cinnamon brown to grayish brown with lighter spots on the belly and neck.

 

Habitat and Reproduction: These mammals have preferably clear bodies of water as their habitat, although they have also been observed in bodies of water with more sediment. Their gestation period can vary from 56 to 86 days according to research reports and observations in zoos; the number of offspring per birth can be from 1 to 5.

 

Importance: Considering the current transformation of aquatic ecosystems, otters become bio-indicators to monitor the ecological functionality of ecosystems, as they are animals that apparently inhabit little intervened water bodies.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Tapir Tapirus terrestris

 

General characteristics: The tapir is a large perissodactyl mammal, in adulthood can weigh between 150 to 250 kg, its fur is short blackish to brown and has a pronounced crest and short horn. It feeds on flowers and fruits and is a good swimmer.

 

Habitat and reproduction: This species occupies a great variety of habitats ranging from dry areas such as the guajira to the forests in the Amazon, passing through the savannas of the eastern plains, being important the presence of water bodies. As for the gestation time of 14 months and the birth is of a single calf that remains with the mother for approximately 2 years.

 

Importance: It is an excellent seed disperser and in the eastern plains it is important in the dispersion of the moriche palm Mauritia flexuosa.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Jaguar Phantera onca

 

General characteristics: This majestic mammal is considered the largest feline in America, its fur is yellow on the back with black spotted patterns unique to each individual, although sometimes you can find melanic individuals of black or brown coloration. Its weight can range between 40 and 90 kg depending on whether the individual is male or female.

 

Habitat and diet: Jaguars inhabit ecosystems such as tropical forests, mountain forests, tropical savannahs and mangroves. Being carnivorous felines, their diet is based on the consumption of meat from prey that they can stalk and hunt, such as peccaries, chigüiros and even caimans.

 

Importance: Being a predator that occupies a large territory, it is important in the control of populations of the species it consumes and the preservation of the ecosystems it inhabits.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Anteater Myrmecophaga tridactyla and Honey bear Tamandua tetradactyla

 

Characteristics and differences: These 2 species are generally known as anteaters, although we find well-marked differences such as size, the palm bear being larger, with rough fur between black, gray and white, and a tail with abundant hair that serves to cover itself at the time of rest; while the honey bear is much smaller, its coat color is yellow and thick and its tail has little hair.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Habitat and diet: These species are found in humid forests, rainforests and savannahs, they feed mainly on ants and termites that they catch with their long, sticky tongue after tearing ant hills and termite mounds with their claws; in the case of palm bears there are reports of consuming chizas or mojojoy and bee larvae.

 

Importance: As their diet is specialized, they become biological controllers of termite and ant populations.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Reptiles

 

Turtles

 

Turtles are a group of chelonian reptiles, characterized by a shell that covers and protects their internal organs, and where they can hide their limbs and head to defend themselves from predators. They are oviparous, and dig their nests in the ground to incubate their eggs. They do not have teeth, but they have a strong beak to capture their prey, which can be fish, plants, insects and worms depending on the tastes of each species. They are long-lived animals that can live between 50 and 80 years.

 

In Casanare the most representative species are:

 

Morrocoy: Chelonoidis carbonaria

 

Its carapace is black or dark brown, with orange-reddish spots or yellow-orange spots, they can measure between 30 and 35 cm in length.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Galapaga or savanna: Podocnemis vogli

 

Its shell can vary from light brown to olive green with a smooth texture and oval shape. Its size can range from 17 to 36 cm in length, with females reaching the largest size.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Hicotea: Trachemis callirostris

 

Its carapace is green with black spots on the marginal scales and the head is olive green, with yellow longitudinal lines and yellow spots on the chin and jaw. This species does not exceed 35 cm in adulthood.

 

Humans have generated a drastic decrease in the populations of these turtle species, increasing their risk of extinction, either by hunting, consumption of their eggs, sale of hatchlings as pets and damage to their habitat.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Caiman llanero Crocodylus intermedius and Cachirre Paleosuchus trigonatus

 

These reptiles are of great ecological importance since, as predators, they play a fundamental role in the flow of energy in the ecosystem they inhabit, which is generally associated with bodies of water, and they also exercise biological control over the species they consume.

 

The llanero caiman is one of the largest crocodiles in the world and is located in the Orinoco basin between Colombia and Venezuela.

 

Its population has been drastically affected by indiscriminate hunting for its skin and meat consumption.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content: On the other hand, the smaller cachirre is considered the second smallest crocodilian in the world, its diet is composed of invertebrates and small vertebrates that it hunts either in the water or on land.

pill.title: Wildlife
pill.content:
Eunectes murinus and Boa constrictor guinea pigs

 

The black guio or anaconda (Eunectes murinus) and the Boa constrictor (Boa constrictor) are constrictor snakes, which means that they constrict their prey with the strength of their bodies when capturing them, since they do not have venom. They can reach a large size and for this reason they are known and representative in the eastern plains. They are found in the wooded savannahs, swamps and near water sources for their displacement since they are good swimmers.

 

The main characteristic of the anaconda is its large size, as it can weigh up to 250 kg and measure approximately 9 meters. Its body is olive in color with oval-shaped black spots on the back and black spots with ochre on the sides of its body.

 

The coloration of the dorsal side of the guio is grey with brown or lighter spots on the inside. They can reach up to 5.5 m in length depending on food availability or the sex of the animal.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content:
Birds are a group of vertebrate animals found in most ecosystems of the planet, they are characterized by the presence of feathers, beak and legs usually with claws depending on the type of food and taxonomic classification. They are numerous and diverse in terms of size, coloration, feeding habits and behavior.

 

Ecologically they play a very important role, since we find birds that disperse seeds, recycle and transform waste and control biological species. In Casanare inhabit diversity of birds that unfortunately face threat to their survival due to the destruction, fragmentation of their habitat and depending on the species human consumption.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content:
Herons

 

The herons are a group of stylized and representative birds of Casanare, within which you can find several species such as the brown heron Ardea cocoi, the grey heron Ardea alba, the blue heron Egretta caeruela and the corocora Eudocimus ruber among others. Heron feeding is based on fish consumption and we can find them resting in groups of different species in the same place.

 

Brown heron: inhabits savannas, marshes and gallery forests near bodies of water.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content: Grey heron: It can be found in savannas, marshes and edges of gallery forests.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content: Blue heron: This species is found in savannas, marshes and gallery forests.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content: Corocora: This bird is found in the natural savannah and also consumes insects as part of its diet.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content:
Red-billed Curassow Ortalis ruficauda

 

This bird of diurnal habits is common in the region, generally groups of up to 6 individuals are observed vocalizing noisily in the gallery forests and stubble areas.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content:
Aruco Anhima cornuta

 

This bird of diurnal habits is associated with bodies of water such as rivers, lagoons, marshes and estuaries, its diet is based on floating vegetation of the places it inhabits; they can be found in groups of up to 5 individuals.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content:
Gaboon Cicconia maguari and Mycteria americana

 

The Pioneer stork Cicconia maguari and the American stork Mycteria americana are diurnal birds that can be seen in open savannahs or marshes, although the Pioneer stork is only seen at certain times of the year. They feed on aquatic invertebrates and small terrestrial vertebrates.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content:
Ducks

 

In the region you can find several species of ducks such as the Brazilian duck Amazonetta brasiliensis, Pato güiriri Dendrocygna viduata and duck Neochen jubata. These species are diurnal and their diet is based on vegetation and small invertebrates.

 

The Brazilian duck is found in marshes and flooded savannahs in groups of up to 20 individuals.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content: The güiriri duck is associated with bodies of water such as rivers, marshes, swamps and wetlands, and flocks of more than 1,000 individuals can be found in summer.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content: The wigeon is found mainly in flooded savannas and estuaries in flocks of approximately 2,000 or more individuals.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content:
Chenchena Opisthocomus hoazin

 

This species has several common names such as pava hedionda, serere and hoatzin among others. It inhabits the interior of gallery forests always associated with bodies of water. It has both diurnal and nocturnal habits and can feed on leaves and fruits. It presents noisy vocalizations of various types, which makes it even more striking.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content:
Crax alberti willow

 

The size of this bird ranges between 80 and 90 cm in length, it lives in forests and can be observed in any forest stratum. It feeds on seeds, insects, flowers, fruits, worms, large arthropods and others and plays an important role in seed dispersal.

pill.title: Birds
pill.content:
Coteras Aramides cajaneus

 

Also known as chilacoa and for its song during the whole day, it lives in the gallery forests, being its main food invertebrates. Its habits can be both diurnal and nocturnal.

question.question: The animals that are used as support in the plain work are:

pill.title: Curiosities
pill.content:
Did you know that...

 

All over the world the different species of fauna have many common names, but their scientific name is universal...

for example, the anteater is known as the anteater, yurumi, tamandua flag and this can lead to confusion when identifying a species...

But if we say Myrmecophaga tridactyla everywhere it lives it will be more easily identified without any doubt or confusion.

question.question: The mule is a hybrid resulting from a cross between a donkey and a mare.

posts.title: Historic Sites
posts.description: To know and value the historical processes that took place in the department of Casanare.

pill.title: Contents
pill.content:
1. Petroglyphs
    1.1. Sabanalarga: The Stone of the Ancestors
2. Vestiges
    2.1. Pore: Architectural ensemble vestiges of the church - jail - chapter house
3. Museum
    3.1. Yopal: 8 de Julio House Museum
    3.2. Orocue: House where José Eustasio Rivera lived - Autor Vorágine
4. Theme park
    4.1. Orocue: Wisirare Park
    4.2. Yopal: Stone Stories Theme Park
5. Historic Centers
    5.1. Historic center Nunchia
    5.2. Tamara Historical Center

pill.title: Introduction
pill.content:
Welcome: The department of Casanare has great historical and cultural wealth that we can see reflected in their municipalities, hence the importance that we know this great wealth.

 

I invite you to visit these wonderful places.

pill.title: Petroglyphs
pill.content: Cave art is a language that is presented as a cultural manifestation of the ancestors who inhabited the places where they are now, can be on stone or earth, are part of the history of humanity being invaluable presence and we can see them in various parts of our country.

pill.title: Petroglyphs
pill.content:
Sabanalarga: The Stone of the Ancestors

 

In the municipality of Sabanalarga, in the village of Palmichal, is located the stone of the ancestors; there are several petroglyphs that reflect the cosmological thought of approximately 10,000 years ago.

 

At present, anthropological studies are being carried out on these petroglyphs to identify which civilization they belong to and to determine their great historical and cultural value, which is undoubtedly very broad and representative for the department of Casanare.

pill.title: Vestiges
pill.content: In the historical context, vestiges refer to the remains, traces or pieces of structures that indicate the presence of an object or place from the past; they provide us with important information about what they were and become a historical source of interest for humanity.

pill.title: Vestiges
pill.content:
Pore: Architectural ensemble vestiges of the church - jail - chapter house

 

San José de Pore, is a municipality of Casanare that is located 70 km from Yopal, is listed as a National Historical and Cultural Heritage, which makes it a great cultural, historical and tourist interest in our country.

 

This municipality was part of the liberation campaign of the new grenade and its streets tell the bravery of the llaneros in this important event for the history of our country.

 

Nowadays, in Pore you can find the remains of buildings from the colonial times such as the Jesuit convent and the jail, which keep stories of independence and inquisition. During the time of the Spanish Inquisition they were built to imprison those who refused to convert to the word of God and did not recognize the kings of Spain as their sovereigns.

pill.title: Vestiges
pill.content: In the cathedral there are still remains of the bell tower and the façade, and where the central nave used to be, there is now a park and a sports field. As for the jail you can still see a wall and parts of an arch. These ruins make the municipality of Pore a place with historical richness and tourist potential where Colombians and foreigners can appreciate the evidence of the history of our wonderful

pill.title: Museum
pill.content: Museums are places of historical importance that show the patrimonial, cultural, natural and artistic richness of a country or specific region, since they contain the human expression through time. Currently we find virtual tour museums, mobile museums and conventional museums that are fixed in multiple cities.

pill.title: Museum
pill.content:
Yopal: 8 de Julio House Museum

 

The 8 de Julio House Museum in the municipality of Yopal is located at Carrera 20 # 7-02; it offers visitors permanent and temporary exhibits that seek to promote the history and culture of the llanera (plains). In the permanent exhibition room documents, photographs and historical objects of Yopal are exhibited; in the temporary exhibition rooms works of local and national artists are exhibited. In addition, there is a cultural agenda that includes events such as conferences, concerts, plays, audiovisual projections and dances.

 

This place of great cultural interest for the department promotes and encourages citizen participation, cultural and academic exchange and creativity contributing to the preservation of the culture and identity of the llanera.

 

To keep up to date with the programming offered by the museum you can enter the Facebook page and schedule your visit.

pill.title: Museum
pill.content:
Orocue: House where José Eustasio Rivera lived - Autor Vorágine

 

In the municipality of Orocue Casanare, is located La Casa Amezquita which is considered an icon in the history of literature in our country, because in this place stayed the lawyer and poet José Eustasio Rivera and in this same enclosure was inspired to write several of his works including the most representative La Vorágine.

 

The Amezquita house dates from 1898 and is preserved thanks to the management of the Isana Foundation in agreement with the University of La Salle. It is currently known as La Casa Museo La Vorágine and in its tour you can learn about relevant aspects of the life and work of José Eustasio Rivera, such as his life in the plains, the history of the municipality of Orocue and various aspects of the life of the plains and Orinoquia. It is also a space for the realization of cultural and pedagogical events of the region; undoubtedly an icon of the material heritage of the municipality and the nation.

gallery.title: Orocue the cradle of the Voragine

pill.title: Theme Park
pill.content:
Currently around the world have been consolidating attractive places for tourism of all ages, each with striking themes and various attractions, this concept is known as "theme park" and can vary its intentionality either to raise awareness about the protection of the environment, fauna and flora or in specific areas such as mathematics, science or technology among others.

 

Orocue: Wisirare Park

 

The Wisirare Biopark is located in the municipality of Orocue, has an area of 1300 hectares and has 2 lagoons originated by the hand of man, which are currently very important for waterfowl that find there an excellent place in summer.

 

In this park, thanks to the Palmarito Foundation, research projects focused on the protection and conservation of endangered species such as the caiman, the babilla and the terecay and charapa turtles are carried out; environmental awareness work is also carried out with the young people of the municipality.

pill.title: Theme Park
pill.content: This park is open to the public free of charge, it can be visited on foot, by motorbike or car and you can appreciate the beautiful landscapes, the fauna and how species conservation projects are developed.

gallery.title: Wisirare Biopark in the municipality of Orocue

pill.title: Theme Park
pill.content:
Yopal: Stone Stories Theme Park

 

In the village of Buena Vista in the municipality of Yopal is located the theme park Stories of stone, an artistic place in a rocky area that has been carved turning the rocks into magnificent figures typical of the eastern plains.

pill.title: Theme Park
pill.content:
It has an ecological trail of approximately 350 meters, where there are about 15 impressive figures of religious, pre-Columbian and plains fauna, carved by a sculptor of the region Oscar Ruiz.

 

To learn more about this amazing place you can visit the Facebook page https://www.facebook.com/historiasdepiedra/ where you can find out first hand the news and services of the park.

pill.title: Historic Centres
pill.content:
In the department of Casanare we find two important historical centers in the preservation of the culture and identity of the region; Nunchia and Támara.

 

Nunchia Historical Center

 

This municipality of the department of Casanare was the scene of the passage of the liberating route and historically is recognized as the area of the green river, valley of the moon or rest of the liberating route, which makes the municipality a place recognized since its founding to date, being a historical, economic, social and cultural reference of the Casanareños.

pill.title: Historic Centres
pill.content:
There are several places where illustrious characters stayed, such as the house where General Santander and his troops spent the night, the house of the tailor Daniel Valdiri and the mansion that housed General Rafael Uribe Uribe, among others. As cultural tourism Nunchía has several attractions within the historical heritage as the monuments to Salvador Camacho Roldán and the tribute to the Liberation Campaign.

 

Nunchia was one of the first municipalities to be founded in the department and the eastern region of the plains, the historic center is marked by the church, although it is simple evidence of its colonial past; the central park where the institutional entities are located and place where the different cultural activities of the municipality are generated.

pill.title: Historic Centres
pill.content:
Támara Historical Center

 

Támara is a historical, cultural and architectural heritage municipality of the department of Casanare that offers its visitors an urban landscape mostly composed of colonial style houses and cobblestone streets; it was founded in 1628 in colonial times, characterized as a coffee center of the region and since then coffee represents its main agricultural and commercial activity.

 

The indigenous people who inhabited Támara and its surroundings collected large loads of cotton a year, which represented a great commercial importance in the region. In the year 1625 the Jesuits arrived in the municipality, where they found fertile and prosperous lands that over the years became the place we know today.

question.question: The department of Casanare has great historical and cultural wealth that we can see reflected in its municipalities, hence the importance of knowing this great wealth.

pill.title: Curiosities
pill.content:
Did you know that...

 

The participation of the Casanareños in the liberation campaign was fundamental to define the independence of our country. Thanks to these brave people from many historic municipalities, today we are proud to be "llaneros".

posts.title: Monumentos
posts.description: To know the concepts of public art, tangible and intangible heritage as well as the importance of monuments and historical sites.

pill.title: Contents
pill.content:
1. Public art
2. Nunchia

3. San Luis de Palenque

5. Aguazul

    5.2. Joropo Instruments: Four

6. Villanueva

pill.title: Introduction
pill.content:
Welcome:

 

The Real Estate heritage is made up of the places, sites, buildings, engineering works, industrial centers, architectural complexes, and monuments of interest or relevant value from the architectural, archaeological, ethnological, historical, artistic or scientific point of view, recognized and registered. as such.

 

In the region there are numerous immovable cultural assets, which tell relevant stories of the places and make populations visible.

 

In this lesson you will get to know some of the monuments and iconic places of Casanare as well as the traditional constructions. This information will allow you to understand in a simple way not only the stories behind these places of interest but also the importance of these as material and immovable heritage of Colombia.

pill.title: Public art
pill.content:
Public art is all that which takes place in places of public access (and in this sense the streets or squares of cities continue to be the spaces that, due to their accessibility, influx and diversity of people who pass through them, best exemplify that location. of “the public”), this would be just a condition, linked to the debate around the interchangeability of the public-private limits. This debate is perhaps the most interesting at a time when the boundaries between public and private are blurred, especially as a result of the incursion of new technologies in the home and in the structures of the city (television and the Internet; video surveillance cameras and mass media, etc.) The idea of a public art today acquires a new dimension inevitably linked to an ideological factor,

 

According to the German philosopher Jürgen Habermas, the concept of public space can be defined as a specific social sphere, and ideally as a place of debate where all citizens can develop and exercise their political will. Hence, it becomes relevant to scrutinize the degree of manifest commitment towards this context, both on the part of the artist and the Institution from which the proposals are formulated and / or accepted, and, therefore, observe from what global and local conception of cities and their public spheres, a type of art destined for public places is promoted, managed and finally developed.

pill.title: Nunchia
pill.content:
Bolivar stone.

 

According to history, it was the place where on June 26, 1819, the liberating army commanded by Bolívar, Santander, Anzoátegui and the fierce llaneros, among whom were Antonio Atanasio Barragán, a native of Pore, Ramón Nonato Pérez, a native of Trinidad and the Brothers Celedonio and Rozo Sánchez, natives of Morcote, a village in the Municipality of Paya, began the ascent to cross the mountain range and descend to the final battles of Pantano de Vargas and Puente de Boyacá, where the independence of Colombia was sealed.

pill.title: Nunchia
pill.content:
Tocaría river bridge.

 

In the months of December to March, the Tocaría river becomes the first-rate natural attraction for bathing the river and the "pot walk" activity for the preparation of the famous chicken stew, tasted on the river bank, with the well-known passage through the "suspension bridge".

pill.title: San Luis de Palenque
pill.content:
Pier.

 

It is located in San Luis de Palenque, a town that stands out for being the navel of Casanare, every morning it wakes up with the calls of the flying boats that arrive and leave by the Pauto River, the main tourist attraction in addition to being the fastest way to get to the town center.

 

The boardwalk is a very pleasant place to visit with friends and family during the day or at night. This beautiful place is located on the banks of the river.

pill.title: Yopal
pill.content:
El Resurgimiento Park.

 

Among its most outstanding features are the green areas and spaces for artistic and cultural events, including the International Festival 'El Cimarrón de Oro'. However, the park is also a nucleus of historical diffusion. There, a sculpture in homage to the troops commanded by Colonel Ramón Nonato Pérez commemorates the effort of the llaneros who participated in the independence struggles. The bronze work, approximately 6 m high, is located on the side of the park, on 16th Street. This attraction also has sports areas, a bike path, flower beds and nature trails.

 

In this place, the Last Tear airport operated in 1938 and 1939, the name was due to the sadness caused by the farewells between travelers and their loved ones.

pill.title: Yopal
pill.content:
Mirador de la Virgen.

 

Cerro El Venado, 2.5 km from the capital, via the electrification plant, rises to show a panorama that combines nature and religious tradition. The sculpture in honor of the Virgin of Manare, patron saint of the Casanareños, is located there. The work, 15 m high, and made by the artist Víctor Salamanca Medina, has become a local pilgrimage sanctuary.

 

At Easter, for example, thousands of faithful arrive in the capital to undertake a journey to the top of the viewpoint. Already at the top, the image of the Virgin and the panoramic view of the city invite you to a moment of calm and evocation.

 

Our lady of sorrows of manare, is recognized as "the virgin of the good trip" to whom the llaneros entrusted themselves in their travels through the vast plains.

 

Her concept was introduced into the Llanera culture by a Spanish Jesuit known as Father José Guimilla who took it in 1712 to the Beyoté region, a Colombian indigenous ethnic group that settled on the banks of the Cravo River in the Tame-Arauca region, when it disappeared. Beyoté, remained in the Manare region to whom it owes its current name until the disappearance of the town and its new relocation and foundation currently known as Paz de Ariporo - Casanare where it currently resides and is venerated.

 

Its incidence in the llanera culture has led it to be an emblematic symbol and its veneration has spread throughout the plains, that is why its rulers have placed it as a symbol of protection for all the inhabitants of the city of Yopal - Casanare .

pill.title: Aguazul
pill.content:
Harp Monument.

 

The Government of Casanare delivered the largest harp in the world With 13 meters high, 5.80 wide and 2.50 deep.

 

The work created by the Llanero sculptor Diego García was called “Las 32¨ (referring to the 32 strings of the harp). It was produced with the rusty steel sheet assembly technique, it guarantees the resistance and durability of the sculpture for several decades.

 

This piece located in the Parque de Arroz de Aguazul has now become synonymous with innovation and creativity in the region, not only because of the aesthetic and interactive concept, but because there is no similar project or of its style, nor a llanera harp of a larger size like that contemplated in this monumental piece.

 

This permanent artistic exhibition aims to recognize musical customs, transmitting them in a lively and direct way, generating feelings of identity, roots, belonging and historical continuity, promoting culture and complementing a tourist and cultural attraction of national impact with the universal language of art.

pill.title: Aguazul
pill.content:
Monument four.

 

Located in the El Cristal neighborhood park, the piece was created by the llanero sculptor Diego García and was called "El Serenatero", a tribute to the llanero musical instrument the four and the great interpreters who contribute with their talent, passion and discipline to the construction of the country's sound heritage.

 

The monument measures 8.50 meters and was made of 1-inch steel, 100% made by Casanareñas hands.

pill.title: Aguazul
pill.content:
Monument to the victims.

 

The monument to the victims of the municipality was made by the Boyacá sculptor Julián Prieto with a welding technique made with scrap metal. With his hands he tried to interpret the feelings of the victims of violence in Casanare.

 

Aguazul human rights defender Lida Quevedo pointed out that it is a space to remember the victims, to be visible, to be heard and to be remembered so as not to repeat history.

 

Quevedo explained that the work symbolizes the men and women victims of the plains. "With his hand on his heart, he expresses the pain because his family has been taken from him and an angel emerges that symbolizes spirituality, love, child victims."

gallery.title: General view Monument to the victims
Close-up view Monument to the victims

pill.title: Villanueva
pill.content:
Monument to the victims.

 

With the name of 'Resilience' it was called the monumentBuilt in commemoration of the victims of the armed conflict, it is made up of the figure of a butterfly, symbolizing metamorphosis, that is, that human beings have the ability to overcome adversity. Made with vehicle parts and elements, the strong and striking colors make it relevant in the main park of Villanueva.

pill.title: Villanueva
pill.content:
Monument to the work of plain.

 

Four characters are part of the scene; the horse, the cow and two cowboys. Made of fiberglass and its golden appearance represents its value. Conceived from the theme of plainness, based on the taste of the inhabitants for folklore and culture, this model was thought, which personifies the cowboys, for its essence and feeling for work. Located in the roundabout of the municipal hospital, on the Marginal de la Selva.

gallery.title: the horse, the cow and two cowboys
the horse, the cow and two cowboys monument

pill.title: Maní
pill.content:
Monument to Guadalupe Salcedo.

 

Located at the entrance of the municipality, this monument made of solid bronze, was built with the purpose of honoring the courage of those young men and peasants of Casanare (Guadalupanos) who during the time of violence (1948-1953) under the command of Commander Guadalupe Salcedo, formed the liberal guerrilla (rabble) and participated in an armed confrontation with the conservative army (chulavitas).

 

Although it could be given a meaning allusive to violence. This monument has as its emblem on its plaque “to remember the history of a war in its just and legitimate time, where brave and brave llaneros, with nobility of heart, defended their land. But today they understand that violence was never the way and that victory can only be reached through the path of peace ”.

pill.title: Maní
pill.content:
La Bandola Monument

 

It is the main monument of the municipality of Maní, it represents the flagship instrument of the Municipality, which makes it known as the Land of the Bandola, thought in honor of those who keep this musical legacy alive, preserving the authentic style of its origins, executed by many generations, which is why the Pedro Flórez international festival is held every year in January.

 

The monument was built in 2010 by the Municipal Administration of the time, measures 10 meters high, from its pedestal, weighs four tons, is made of composite aluminum and has a lighting system with LED sequencers.

 

It was assembled in Bogotá, by the Mexican company SAVIV SA, for its transportation it was necessary to use a 20-meter mule-tractor and for its installation a PH crane and more than 30 people.

pill.title: Maní
pill.content:
Pier.

 

Built in 2011 by the municipal administration, it was mainly conceived as a work for the promotion of tourism and beautification of the municipality, its functionality as a protection work against the rising of the river thanks to the 200 linear meters built as gabions that border the riverbank . To recreate the most representative plains fauna, a chigüiro, a cachicamo, an iguana, a morrocoy, a deer, giant chair-shaped sculptures, meticulously carved in cement and painted with great detail, were also built on the site.

 

Others very visited are El Canoero, who with paddle in hand leads his curara with the occasional passenger who dares to board. This boardwalk is also guarded by the monument to the Llanera Woman and the Mohán of the legend, sculptures made to honor myths and legends of the municipality and the woman of the territory, brave, hard-working and loving.

pill.title: Orocue
pill.content:
The boardwalk on the Meta River is located on the Northeast side of the municipal urban area. It is the old river port where commercial exchanges were made between Colombia, Venezuela, France and Germany; A situation that led to the creation of a national customs office at that time, generating the impulse of steam navigation and economic and business growth.

 

Currently there is a modern infrastructure, represented by a boardwalk with a distance of 1 km. On its path you can see a mixture between its history and its current architecture, finding places and images of great importance and contribution to the municipality such as the National Army, Statue of the Virgin of the Pillar, The bust of Juan Bautista de la Salle, tree of inspiration for José Eustasio Rivera in his
La Vorágine, Kiosco Don Juanito, two viewpoints, sculptures of the plains region, plains square.

 

Likewise, you can enjoy the recreation of the emblematic work of the Vorágine through paintings during the tour, to end in what is the main port of Orocué.

 

Among the activities to be developed you can do guided tours, shopping, gastronomy and anthropological knowledge.

pill.title: Hato Corozal
pill.content:
Monument tribute to Bonifacio Gutiérrez.

 

This monument is also a tribute to the joropo, it is composed of a trio of harp, four and maracas.

 

Bonifacio Gutiérrez was one of the 14 llaneros commanded by Colonel Juan José Rondón who went to the 'Pantano de Vargas' to collaborate with Simón Bolívar when everything was about to be lost.

pill.title: Property and Property
pill.content:
Material Heritage.

 

Material heritage refers to tangible assets of movable and immovable nature, which are characterized by having a special historical, artistic, scientific, aesthetic or symbolic interest in areas such as plastic, architectural, urban, archaeological, linguistic, sound, musical, audiovisual, filmic, testimonial, documentary, literary, bibliographic, museological or anthropological, among others.

 

Property Assets.

 

The real estate includes urban sectors, sets of buildings in public space and buildings of residential, institutional, commercial, industrial, military, religious architecture, for transport and engineering works that give account of a distinctive and representative physiognomy, characteristics and values for a community.

pill.title: Herds and plains constructions
pill.content:
Llanero herd.

 

The traditional cattle herd has at least 1,000 cattle, foundations and a particular social structure, dominated by hierarchies related to the jobs of the Llano. The cattle farm is the one with less than 1,000 cattle, few permanent employees, and no foundations.

 

The conuquero or veguero farms are located on the banks of the rivers and vary in extension from 1,000 to 50 ha; they generally dedicate a large part of the area to raising and raising cattle.

 

The farm or herd with temporary rice agribusiness is the one that rents a part of the herd to rice farmers for three harvests. The farm in the foothills for fattening cattle is the one used to fatten them and is generally located near the main roads.

 

The traditional llanero herd has changed rapidly in the foothills, where modern production technologies based on pasture and improved cattle have been implemented. In this strip, new forms of cultivation of selected varieties of rice and corn are also practiced and the gigantic plantations of African palm, rubber and Caribbean pine, slowly invade the savannas and transform the landscape.

pill.title: Herds and plains constructions
pill.content:
Llanero ranch.

 

It is said that the design of the llanera house is a combination between the indigenous house and the models that the Jesuits contributed when they were in the plains there in the 1630s. Soropo, bahareque and adobe have been used as patterns in its construction for the llanera housing, the roof is made of palm, very few use the moriche, the tread wall and the cement block walls were used; pressed brick and cement cladding with colorful paints to suit all tastes.

 

The soropo is the home of the llanero where, it is believed that the joropos were made, this house is roofed with stalks of dried royal palm and cut in decline.

 

The partitions of the rooms and the doors are made of the same material and only palm, wood and liana are involved. The floor is made of clay soil that is set with rammers, using pieces of fine wood of 30 to 35 cm; that are assembled on a rope. Like that of the shovel and it is used to settle the half-wet earth of the floors.

 

The savannah plainsman builds a very own house called a half wall, built in adobe with bahareque, it is made as an exterior wall that protects the corridors, a small wall that surrounds the house allowing ventilation and protecting itself from the rain.

 

Another different house, much more rustic, is the one that is built for the estates or the foundations where it is planned to create a herd over time. Its base is made of stepped clay and the walls or divisions can be made of wood, bareque or clay brick. Its roof in royal palm or moriche palm.

pill.content:
Did you know that...

 

The bandola monument located in Maní was built by the same manufacturers of the famous Hard Rock Café guitar that can be found in different cities around the world.
