posts.title: Cultural diversity
posts.description: This Capsule explains about the indigenous reserves and the NARP community in the region.

pill.title: Contents
pill.content:
1. What is an indigenous reguardo?
2. Indigenous reservations and their communities
3. Caño Mochuelo Resguardo
4. What is the NARP community?
5. Sociocultural context of the NARP community in Casanare

pill.title: Introduction
pill.content:
Welcome: In Colombia there are countless cultural manifestations that express the ethnic and religious variety of customs, traditions and ways of life of its population, as well as its natural wealth and diversity of climates, geographies and landscapes, among others.

 

In this lesson you will learn about the NARP and indigenous communities of the region. This information will allow you to easily and quickly understand the most relevant aspects of these cultures that are part of the cultural wealth of the country in all its expressions.

pill.title: What is an indigenous reservation?
pill.content: According to the Ministry of the Interior, indigenous reservations are the collective property of the indigenous communities in favor of which they are constituted and, in accordance with articles 63 and 329 of the Political Constitution, have the character of inalienable, imprescriptible and unattachable. Indigenous reservations are a legal and socio-political institution of a special nature, made up of one or more indigenous communities, which, with a collective property title that enjoy the guarantees of private property, own their territory and are governed for the management of this and their internal life by an autonomous organization protected by the indigenous jurisdiction and its own regulatory system. (Article 21, Decree 2164 of 1995).

pill.title: Indigenous reservations and their communities
pill.content:
Casanare was a region of active pre-Hispanic trade. Upon the arrival of the white man, during the 16th and 17th centuries, this effective trade became a war between the tribes, as the European sought to capture indigenous people for slaves and pay them with artifacts of daily use.

 

The indigenous people found were the Guahibos or Sikuanis, Amoruas, Cuivas, Sálivas, Tunebos and Tsiripu or Mariposos. The Jesuits were the first order of religious who entered the territory of Casanare to evangelize. They founded various haciendas, using the labor of the aborigines and began a tireless struggle to dominate the immense savannah that ran from the foothills of Casanare to the banks of the Orinoco River. This was only achieved in Casanare and part of Meta.

 

Near the Meta river there was a settlement made up of the Surimena, Macuco, Jiramena and Casimena estates; It was located on the right bank of the pipe that bears his name, within the territory that today is Santa Elena de Cúsiva.

 

The population of Casanare is made up of two ethnic elements such as the mestizo-white and the indigenous.

 

At present, there are eight ethnic groups in the Caño Mochuelo reservation. In an area of 94,670 hectares and 3,352 inhabitants, is the community of Orocué; another in an area of 49,338 hectares, made up of 8 reservations of the Sáliva ethnic group, with 1,280 inhabitants; and the Chaparral and Barronegro reservation of the U'wa ethnic group, which comprises an area of 14,230 hectares, with a population of 416, for a total of approximately 5,048 inhabitants.

 

Initially, the flow of immigrants was predominantly white, corresponding to the colonist named for his origin and roots. Later, starting in the 1950s, the migratory process originated mainly from the Cundiboyacense highlands and other regions of the country, which has resulted in an ethnic and cultural variety with very special characteristics.

 

Sociocultural expressions began since the conquest, when the first sociable attempts were made, resulting in a human biotype with a sui generis organization that would learn to live, manage, produce and evolve with the basic elements of a pastoral economy. It should be said that the first settlement with political criteria had its origin on September 27, 1588, when the encomendero Pedro Daza founded the city of Santiago de la Atalayas, an important administrative center that forged the colonial exploitation model.

 

The aboriginal Achaguas and Sálivas, inhabitants of the territory, had a special sensitivity for the arts, especially for music. Of them, many traits, customs, traditions, beliefs and the ancestor in the mestizo man who recognizes his cultural ancestor are still preserved.

pill.title: Caño Mochuelo Resguardo
pill.content: The Caño Mochuelo reservation comprises a territory of 94,670 hectares of plain. In this area, 14 communities of 10 indigenous peoples of the Orinoquía coexist. This territory is composed of a great biodiversity that includes rivers, savannah, among others.

pill.title: Caño Mochuelo Resguardo
pill.content:
Caño Mochuelo is a river star. Water is the element of indigenous communities, the Casanare River passes through the territory to the north and the Meta River to the south. In addition, there are numerous minor streams, estuaries, lagoons and morichales. These two rivers come together and are looking for the Ariporo river and the Aguaclara channel, which cross the entire heart of the reguardo.

 

At the eastern tip, on the border of the department, 47 kilometers from the Venezuelan border, the Ariporo converges in the Casanare and the Aguaclara in the Meta, and then the Casanare in the Meta, which continues its course to the Orinoco.

pill.title: Caño Mochuelo Resguardo
pill.content:
Political structure of the reservation

 

The General Assembly is the highest political-administrative authority of the reguardo. It is made up of 20 representatives of each town and has the function of electing the council of the Cabildo, distributing and executing the budget, and judging and sanctioning in the jurisdiction of the reservation.

 

On the other hand, the Council of Elders is made up of the main traditional authorities of each town, the elders, who guard, interpret and transmit the law of origin, history, knowledge, uses and customs of their cultures and territory.

 

In addition to the above, there is also the figure of the Board of the Indigenous Council, this legally represents the reserve, manages resources and ensures peace and coexistence in the territory. It is made up of the governor, the secretary, the commissioner, the treasurer and the members. The prosecutor is part of the Cabildo Board, but is elected in a separate vote and does not have executive functions.

 

Finally, there is the figure of captains and councilors, these are the local authorities of each community in the reguardo. They are links with the council meeting, other people and organizations that visit the community. They watch over the security of the territory and are in charge of various aspects of community organization. They are chosen according to the customs of each town and community.

pill.title: What is the NARP community?
pill.content:
NARP means (Black, Afro-Colombian, Raizal and Palenquera population. It includes three ethnic groups in the country: Blacks, mulattos, Afro-descendants, Afro-Colombians).

 

Afro-Colombian communities NARP

 

It is the set of families of Afro-Colombian descent that have their own culture, share a history and have their own traditions and customs within the field-town relationship, which reveal and preserve the consciousness and identity that distinguish them from other ethnic groups.

 

Raizal community

 

Population located in the Archipelago of San Andrés, Providencia and Santa Catalina, which has Afro-Anglo-Antillean cultural roots and whose members have socio-cultural and linguistic characteristics clearly differentiated from those of the rest of the Afro-Colombian population.

gallery.title: The untold story of the Afro community

pill.title: Sociocultural context of the NARP community in Casanare
pill.content:
In 1492 a milestone in the history of the native peoples was recorded, known as the discovery of America and which in synthesis brought with it the colonization and expansion of the European empires in the new continent. In the shortest of years, indigenous civilizations and peoples were disappearing due to smallpox, measles, hunting and slavery, until they were reduced to small communities in inaccessible places, which recently began to be recognized and protected, although limited to small reservations and territories.

 

With the colonizers also came black labor from Africa, brought as slaves, which over the years and the independence process managed to form peoples that still retain part of their rich ancestral African culture. In 500 years of history, since colonization, the demographic map of the American continent was completely transformed, to the point that indigenous peoples and Afro-descendants became ethnic minority groups. In the case of Colombia, the current demographic configuration reveals a populationally diverse country, characterized by diversity of races, ethnicities, languages, cultures, beliefs and worldviews throughout its territory, and therefore it is considered a multi-ethnic and multicultural country, whose origin dates back to the time of the Spanish conquest and colonization, which led to the mixture of various ethnic races and cultures such as Aboriginal, African and European. This process has not been peaceful and much less beneficial for everyone; phenomena such as war, forced displacement, colonization of ancestral territories, poverty and marginalization of ethnic communities, state centralism, the design of undifferentiated policies and the very existence of predominant cultures, among many other factors, certify that the process It has not been beneficial for all and that from the very time of colonization we are regressing as a multiethnic and multicultural country, that is, instead of strengthening this connotation, progress has been made in the annihilation of ethnic groups, languages, cultures, beliefs and visions of humanity. Nowadays,

 

For example, the accelerated transformation process of Yopal and the exponential growth of its population indicate that the economic aspect has had an impact on the expansion of the agricultural frontier and the exploration of mining and energy, which has led to migratory processes from the rural area to the urban area and fundamentally an accelerated migratory process from different parts of the national territory, a process that has lasted for little more than three decades. The migration that has given rise to a city of about one hundred and ninety thousand people has come mainly from the Cundiboyacense region given its geographical proximity, but it has also been generated from the Pacific and Atlantic regions. Hence, there is a diverse city in every sense, but it has managed to conserve the invaluable heritage of the Llanera culture. Given the above, Yopal is characterized by being a multiethnic and multicultural city, where there are undoubtedly processes of cultural exchange, which means that there is a mixture of various traditions and the coexistence of various population groups with different histories, rhythms, colors, origins and traditions. In this sense, the NARP population of the Municipality of Yopal is part of that cultural symbiosis, but also in a population group or community that coexists with the conservation of important cultural features, and hence the need to achieve Afro cultural preservation. in our territory, as a factor of development. where there are undoubtedly processes of cultural exchange, which means that there is a mixture of different traditions and the coexistence of different population groups with different histories, rhythms, colors, origins and traditions. In this sense, the NARP population of the Municipality of Yopal is part of that cultural symbiosis, but also in a population group or community that coexists with the conservation of important cultural features, and hence the need to achieve Afro cultural preservation. in our territory, as a factor of development. where there are undoubtedly processes of cultural exchange, which means that there is a mixture of different traditions and the coexistence of different population groups with different histories, rhythms, colors, origins and traditions. In this sense, the NARP population of the Municipality of Yopal is part of that cultural symbiosis, but also in a population group or community that coexists with the conservation of important cultural features, and hence the need to achieve Afro cultural preservation. in our territory, as a factor of development.

 

NARP community regulations in Casanare.

 

in order to guarantee that these communities obtain real conditions of equality of opportunities compared to the rest of Colombian society. In accordance with the provisions of Paragraph 1 of transitory article 55 of the Political Constitution. In the Department of Casanare, according to the 2018 census, the Black, Afro-Colombian, Raizal and Palenqueras population is 6,089 self-recognized Afro-Colombian inhabitants, a high percentage of this population have migrated to the Department for different causes, among which is Violence in their territories, forced displacement, job opportunities and study among other causes. From the Government of Casanare, headed by the Departmental Government Secretary, the Project called: STRENGTHENING ORGANIZATIONAL, SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT, is being developed.

 

Normativity.

posts.title: Organic pineapple venture
posts.description: This Capsule explains what entrepreneurship is, its types, organic products and success stories in the region.

pill.title: Content
pill.content:
1. What is entrepreneurship?
2. Types of entrepreneurship
3. Agricultural and livestock ventures
4. Organic products: a business opportunity
5. Organic pineapple business in Casanare.

pill.title: Introduction
pill.content:
Entrepreneurship is an exciting topic and of great relevance for a State and its society, since thanks to entrepreneurship, economies are energized, contributing positively in the stabilization of these and in the generation of jobs.


Recently the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor (GEM) published a report in which Colombia stands out in the 4th position in the rate of entrepreneurial activity in early stage (TEA) worldwide, in addition to this it is also worth noting that, in the participation by gender, in the TEA worldwide the country presented very positive results, as the propensities to create companies of women were very close to those of men.


Finally, this report reveals that Colombia is the country with the lowest self-confidence in the Latin American region in terms of knowledge, skills and experience. It is also one of the countries with the least fear of failure as an inhibiting factor for entrepreneurship.


In the following lessons you will learn the basics of entrepreneurship as well as the mega trends of the global market, business opportunities and entrepreneurships in the region that are already doing it.

pill.title: What is entrepreneurship?
pill.content:
Entrepreneurship is a term that has recently been widely used around the world. Although entrepreneurship has always been present throughout the history of mankind, as it is inherent to it, in recent decades this concept has become of utmost importance due to the need to overcome the constant and growing economic problems.

 

The word entrepreneurship comes from the French entrepreneur (pioneer), and refers to the ability of a person to make an extra effort to achieve a goal or objective, being also used to refer to the person who started a new company or project, a term that was later used to refer to the person who started a new company or project, a term that was later used to refer to the person who started a new company or project.

 

This term was later applied to entrepreneurs who were innovators or who added value to an existing product or process, which today has resulted in the current concept of entrepreneurship.

 

In conclusion, entrepreneurship is that attitude and aptitude of the person that allows him/her to initiate new challenges, new projects; it is what allows him/her to go one step further, to go beyond where he/she has already arrived. It is what makes a person dissatisfied with what he is and what he has achieved, and as a consequence, wants to achieve more and start new paths.

 

On the other hand, an entrepreneurship project is the enterprise or project that is initiated in order to build or achieve something.

 

Therefore, to undertake means to act or initiate actions to materialize or materialize something, which in the business field translates into the creation of companies and businesses.

pill.title: Types of entrepreneurship
pill.content:
1. Small businesses

 

These are small businesses created to promote self-employment, such as hairdressers, bakeries or small cafés. They are generally owner-managed, have few employees, and most of them are usually family members. Most of these enterprises generate a minimum of profitability sufficient to support the family and cover expenses.

 

Characteristics

 

  • They usually do not create anything new, but they do meet market needs.
  • They are timely, as they always meet a local need. In many cases people prefer to go to a nearby bakery rather than to a more remote bakery. This will happen as long as they have a good combination of price, service and product.
  • While they do require capital to get started, it is not as high as in technology ventures. In many cases, these types of ventures start with their own capital.
  • They are local ventures, with no intention of going international. They aspire to progress in the locality where they are developed.

 

2. Scalable ventures

 

These types of ventures create repeatable and scalable business models. Their purpose is to achieve high levels of growth. They are usually of a technological nature, related to the development of software and electronic devices. They can achieve high growth in a short period of time. For this reason, there are venture capital investors who bet large sums of money in apparently incipient businesses.

 

'Rappi' is an example of a scalable venture. As of 2018, it had received almost $500 million from venture funds and subsequently received a $1 billion equity investment from Japan's SoftBank Group. Thanks to these capital injections, Rappi has been able to scale its business model in each country where it operates.


Characteristics

 

  • Its strategies are focused on innovation, with the purpose of scaling.
  • They use all possible strategies to enter the market.
  • They require high levels of financing. Once they find the appropriate model, venture capital becomes necessary for rapid expansion.
  • They seek internationalization. Generally, this type of innovation expands in foreign markets.

pill.title: Types of entrepreneurship
pill.content:
3. Large ventures

 

Refers to large companies with finite life cycles. These companies must constantly innovate their products and services in order to stay in the market and grow.

 

A good example of this model of entrepreneurship is Coca Cola. This company has proven to be at the forefront and has become a leader. From the testing of new local products, to the lifting and displacement of successful brands around the world are part of their strategies to stay in the market.

 

 Characteristics

 

  • They are innovative. To stay in the market they constantly study the changes they face, the new trends in customer tastes, technologies, regulations and new proposals from competitors.
  • They must be in a process of continuous research and understanding of market changes in order to take advantage of market opportunities.
  • They spend a large part of their budget on product research and innovation.
  • They are solid companies that have ventured into different markets and that are always at the forefront in order not to disappear. They tend to internationalize.

 

4. Incubator ventures

 

These types of ventures support other companies or ventures. They are in charge of studying a recurring need in the market within a niche. Therefore, they require large investment or funding for these studies and to collect enough data to ensure that the business will work.

 

Ruta N is an important Latin American incubator located in the city of Medellin, Colombia. Its purpose is to support emerging companies and offer advice on investors. This has made it one of the hotbeds of talent in the region,
generating interesting synergies between the public and private sectors. It also supports entrepreneurs seeking to carry out scientific and educational projects.

 

Characteristics

 

  • In this type of entrepreneurship, research focuses on studying market needs that are permanent (not emerging) and innovating on them.
  • Due to the long process of research and development, they tend to predict market changes well. Therefore, they are better prepared to face any kind of adverse situation and take advantage of opportunities.
  • They require high levels of funding to develop their research.
  • Their products seek to position themselves in national and international markets.

pill.title: Types of entrepreneurship
pill.content:
5. Humanistic or social

 

The purpose of these types of ventures is to generate a positive impact on the world. They are usually incorporated as non-profit companies and seek to generate a benefit in sectors related to human rights, education, health, social development and the environment. They seek to succeed through innovation.

 

In 2018, the Forética Report on the evolution of CSR and sustainability found that 48% of its respondents adopted lifestyle habits with a positive impact on society and the environment. This reveals that any social or environmental entrepreneurship also has a guaranteed market.

 

An example of this is the initiative of the sports brand Adidas, which joined forces with the organization Parley For The Oceans. Together they created a model of sneakers made almost entirely from recycled plastic collected from the sea and coastal areas.

 

Characteristics

 

  • Whether they are economically profitable or not, they should always seek innovation to make an impact in the field in which they develop.
  • They always seek to take advantage of the opportunities offered by the business environment to achieve their goals.
  • They obtain financing through public policy programs, private financing or crowdfunding.
  • When these projects achieve a real impact on society, they tend to venture into other international contexts or be imitated.

 

6. Imitation or mirror business

 

There are two classifications of this type of entrepreneurship. One consists of the imitation of a product or service already existing in the market and the other corresponds to the acquisition of a franchise, whose business model is already established.

 

An example of the latter is McDonald's, an American fast food restaurant franchise, based in Illinois, Chicago. Its main products are hamburgers, soft drinks, ice cream, desserts and french fries. It has more than 30 thousand restaurants in more than 100 countries.

 

Characteristics

 

  • Its purpose is to seek profitability through the investment made.
  • The opportunity they seek is to obtain the same success that the product or business model has had.
  • The acquisition of this type of business requires a large amount of capital.
  • In the case of franchises, they are usually foreign business models that enter the regional market.

pill.title: Types of entrepreneurship
pill.content:
7. Technological

 

These are ventures related to science and technology, which manage to revolutionize the world due to their high impact. They can be designed to help us measure or complete everyday tasks and even make use of artificial intelligence to solve problems.

 

Apps for runners, such as 5K Runner or Runkeeper are a good example of how technology can contribute to an easier life and meet our needs. In this case, these tools help runners to have a better control of their routines and workouts.

 

Characteristics

 

  • In many opportunities, these types of ventures arise in universities and are supported by technology parks. They range from technological inventions to robotics.
  • They seek to revolutionize the world with their product or service.
  • They are projects that require high levels of financing for their projection.
  • Their inventions are usually international in scope.

 

8. Digital

 

These refer to commerce carried out through social networks and web pages, known as e-commerce. It can be a product or a service that aims to be profitable through the networks and is intended to satisfy a need.

 

The example par excellence is Amazon, which has changed the concept of selling products, with its variety and 24-hour customer service.

 

Characteristics

 

  • They arise in a context where the opportunity to satisfy a need can be clearly identified.
  • In many cases their financing is minor, as long as they are consulting ventures, where they can be undertaken with their own capital. The situation is different in international product sales businesses, where large amounts of capital are required.
  • The entrepreneurship is exercised through networks, so it has the quality of being easily internationalized.

pill.title: Types of entrepreneurship
pill.content:
9. Public

 

This is the type of entrepreneurship executed by the State through its development agencies. These are aimed at innovation in a social sector, services or innovations in legal regulation.

 

In the Dominican Republic, the government created a service to consult traffic fines and document procedures. In this way, it centralized all procedures in order to make them faster and more transparent for citizens.

 

Characteristics

 

  • They use new technologies to innovate the way of public management.
  • They see the opportunity to improve administrative management, simplifying processes and making management more productive. They eliminate bureaucracy and attack corruption.
  • These projects require high levels of funding, as they must be adapted to all public institutions and, in some cases, require a training process for the administrative sector.

 

10. Productive

 

There are a wide variety of types of productive ventures. In general, they are ventures created with private and public investment. On many occasions, the government establishes alliances with the private sector in order to promote economic and social development in a given region.

 

A good example is the Compra Local platform, sponsored by the Mayor's Office of Medellin in Colombia. The local government, in partnership with the municipality's farmers, created a virtual market for the city's inhabitants to stock up on regionally produced food. In just three days (during the portal's first month), the allied farmers earned 16 million pesos, equivalent to more than US$4,000.

 

Characteristics

 

  • They are usually set up to help people in vulnerable situations.
  • They take advantage of the needs of their locality to undertake and supply their needs.
  • They require funding from the State, which establishes alliances with the private sector, and in many opportunities with international organizations that seek to develop impoverished or vulnerable regions.

pill.title: Agricultural entrepreneurship.
pill.content:
An agricultural entrepreneur is understood as an individual or group that has rights to use and exploit land or other elements to carry out agricultural, forestry or mixed activities, and rural entrepreneurship is understood as the creation of new organizations that generate new markets and products or use new technologies from rural areas. 

 

Today, the contribution of small and medium-sized enterprises to the economy, productivity, innovation, employment, the development of the social fabric and prosperity in general is indisputable.

 

There are studies that show that farmers identify themselves as entrepreneurs or at least consider it possible to become them, however, the strength of the entrepreneurial identity is questioned, for example, a study was conducted in Finland and found that only 40% of farmers had entrepreneurial attitudes and of these, only half had attitudes that reflect a growth orientation and willingness to take risks. In turn, the farmers' problem is not in identifying themselves as entrepreneurs, but arose from the farmers' position in the market and their relationship with customers, especially when the farmer's clientele depends on only one farmer. Thus, there is a need to strengthen entrepreneurial attitudes and initiatives that will enable entrepreneurship to gain strength and position itself with business strategies. At the same time, certain personal characteristics such as self-criticism, leadership, creativity, perseverance and initiative adopted by farmers are necessary for the venture to be successful and sustainable.

 

In addition to the need for certain personal characteristics, agriculture is facing various changes in demand, consumers are aware of genetic modification in animals, chemicals harmful to health contained in plant products and the growing environmental damage, the effect of food production, As a result, legislation is becoming stricter and agricultural entrepreneurship initiatives are increasingly committed to the welfare of animals, the environment and the good use of resources, so that the entrepreneur has to take into account the characteristics of his environment to make the right decisions and allow the business to remain in business. Entrepreneurial initiatives are responsible for economic development, since they generate changes that can become the tool through which problems are solved by means of product and process innovation, market innovation and innovation in organizational forms. Agricultural entrepreneurs must offer high quality products, manufactured in a socially appropriate manner and respecting social values. This illustrates the need for a transition towards a more sustainable agriculture, which is why entrepreneurship appears as an opportunity to find novel and complementary alternatives to development, primarily focused on rural areas.

 

Thus, entrepreneurship initiatives arise with the intention of finding novel and complementary alternatives to development, mainly with regard to a greater concentration and exploitation of business opportunities and generation of wealth in rural areas. Thus, based on the concept of rural or agricultural entrepreneurship together with the reference to rural development, it is proposed that entrepreneurship, through its creation and transformation activities, could generate contributions to the creation of rural development. 

 

In the Colombian case, according to the last part of the first chapter of the peace agreement in Colombia, the importance and need to seek and make changes and transformations to the countryside is highlighted, and in this sense, it is considered that agricultural entrepreneurship could be the tool to carry out changes such as the promotion of commercial activities of the production of the peasant economy, family and community economy and trying to reduce intermediation, financing or co-financing for the production of the peasant, family and community economy, the integration of the countryside with the city through the connection of rural production with other production models, the establishment of a regional price information system.

pill.title: Agricultural entrepreneurship.
pill.content:
In terms of employment and the solution to problems such as informality and high unemployment, the aim is to guarantee labor rights by promoting decent work and social protection, encouraging associative forms based on solidarity and cooperation to facilitate access to state services aimed at the welfare of workers. 

 

In terms of natural resources, the purpose is to delimit the agricultural frontier, protect areas of special environmental interest, guaranteeing care for the environment, generating well-being and good living. 

 

Finally, for the aspect of technification of processes and training of farmers, the aim is to stimulate the processes of technological innovation, guaranteeing integral, technical and technological assistance service to the production of the peasant, family and community economy. Thus, agricultural entrepreneurship could go hand in hand with the aforementioned strategies in order to promote and facilitate the process of transformation of the countryside.

 

Agricultural entrepreneurship is the necessary process to overcome economic, social and environmental problems of the nation, and it is one of the sectors that the Ministry of Commerce, Industry and Tourism has classified as world class, considering that it can become highly competitive and productive by international standards. For professionals who are part of the sector, it is a great opportunity to enter the business world, providing goods and services that have an innovative component, added value and a differentiating factor in order to meet the needs, solve problems and shortages or take advantage of opportunities that national and international markets require. On the other hand, there is a growing demand for entrepreneurs capable of discovering new alternatives and anticipating the transcendental changes that the use of technology is generating.

 

There are great challenges for entrepreneurs in the sector, since new business opportunities must be aligned with the objectives of sustainable development, which are framed, in a special way, with issues directly related to agriculture. Generating businesses under the parameters of corporate social responsibility requires that the new generations of entrepreneurs be aware of the great commitment to the high percentage of the population that cannot access professional training systems, which leads to thinking forcefully about the environmental, social and economic impact that business initiatives must generate. Another challenge and a great opportunity lies in the implementation of the variables that accompany the fourth industrial revolution, with possibilities of application in the sector, as has already been observed.

 

Understanding that the activities that revolve around the agroindustrial sector have to be seen and recognized as profitable business units, starting from the basic equation: 

 

Revenues - expenses = profit or loss.

 

All professionals, regardless of their specific area of knowledge, should know and have a minimum mastery of the financial concepts and fundamentals that are handled on a daily basis in the different transactions that individuals and companies must face. Equal importance should be given to the knowledge demanded by each of the areas that make up the organization.

 

Advantage should be taken of the favorable expectations for the growth of the sector in the medium and long term, accompanied by sources of financing such as the Emprender Fund, which is strongly committed to supporting projects related to agribusiness. In addition to the resources offered through rediscount lines such as Finagro. Unlike other times, today's educational institutions offer among their curricula the possibility for students to acquire entrepreneurial skills, which empower them to go out into the market and fit in the best way in an increasingly demanding system.

pill.title: Organic products: a business opportunity.
pill.content:
It is called organic to all those products that during their growth or development have not been applied synthetic fertilizers, pesticides, genetically modified organisms and pharmaceuticals, according to the International Federation of Organic Agriculture Movements. 

 

Organic food has been produced worldwide for thousands of years, but it has been considered a renaissance since about 40 years ago in Germany and England, when several scientists laid the foundations of what is now organic agriculture through advances in agronomy, phytopathology, chemistry and other sciences. In these countries, the first movements were born to establish healthy food for the family and ensuring that the environment is not affected in the process. 

 

Nowadays, there is greater public interest in the relationship between the environment and the cultivation of agricultural products, favoring the growth of organic farms all over the world. The consumption of organic food is constantly growing in developed countries, due to the increase in consumer demand. This production has been growing significantly and has allowed more and more participants to enter this dynamic, attractive and, above all, lucrative market. The largest consumers are currently Europe and the United States and according to recent data in 2015 it was estimated in 50.9 million hectares in the world dedicated to organic farming, this represents a growth of 6.5 million hectares since 2014 which is a record in this market. Australia is the country with the largest area, bordering 23 million hectares, followed by Argentina with 3 million and the United States with 2 million.

 

Reasons why consumers prefer organic products. 

 

  1. Their taste, color and aroma have a better quality compared to agricultural products that have received pesticides and synthetic fertilizers.
  2. Organic products have many more vitamins, minerals and antioxidants than agricultural products that have been affected with pesticides and synthetic fertilizers.
  3. Because no chemicals are used, organic agriculture protects the health of farmers and consumers.
  4. Organic products are usually certified so there is no way we can be fooled or "taken for a ride".
  5. Organic products are environmentally friendly and prevent global warming.

 

Diversity in organic products.

 

The scope of organic products is not limited to food. Nowadays, an industry has developed with derivatives of organic agricultural products such as organic cotton fibers. There are brands and clothing stores that use only fabrics made from this type of cotton.

 

Another industry that has also developed quite rapidly is the personal care industry (shampoos, soaps, oils, among others). 

 

Benefits of organic products from an entrepreneur's point of view.

 

This is a growing market, which has higher prices and therefore offers higher profit margins. In the organic market there are fewer intermediaries, there is a greater possibility of more direct contact with the buyers of the products. 

 

Since you generally pay higher prices, you will be able to have a higher profit margin, which in turn will allow you to have greater economic flexibility. However, there are also some additional costs to deal with, but if you manage to cope with the difficulties and all the requirements, an organic business can provide more opportunities for profit than conventional businesses.

 

On the other hand, starting to sell organic products online is relatively simple and does not require a large initial investment. All that is needed is a website, a brand name and a source of supplies.

pill.title: Organic products: a business opportunity.
pill.content:
Tips for starting your own organic produce business.

 

If you are interested in starting your own organic produce business you should consider the following tips:

 

1. Follow the rules

 

You should keep in mind that there are rules that cover all sectors of the organic industry. That is why, before launching your business you should do a thorough research and follow the rules, as these are important for the integrity of the organic industry. There are different certificates for these products, whose information can be obtained from the Organic Trade Association website (www.ota.com). Also, keep in mind that there are certain types of organic production that are not covered by the broader organic regulations, such as the manufacture of textiles, cosmetics, etc., which are regulated by private or industry standards.

 

2. Know the ways to market your products

 

You can market your organic products in different points of sale, such as supermarkets, specialized stores, fairs, through the Internet or direct deliveries to users.

 

3. Know what your advantages are over the competition.

 

Although the demand for a certain product is growing in the market, this does not mean that you will be successful in it, since the competition is also greater. Because of this, you must know what your advantages are over your competitors in order to take advantage of them. Not only must you consider the product and the price, but you must also take into account that your product must be reliable, must maintain a certain quality constantly, must have the certifications that guarantee that quality and must have the appropriate logistics to make deliveries quickly.

 

4. Attend trade fairs

 

Whether to present your product or to gain more knowledge about the market or to connect with other vendors or suppliers, it is important that you attend trade fairs where organic products are sold.

 

More and more people worldwide are turning to organic products. While initially driven by a fad that only a few people followed, it has now become a way of life for those seeking protection from the toxins, chemicals, GMOs and preservatives that many commercial products contain today.

pill.title: Organic pineapple enterprises in Casanare.
pill.content:
In 2019, an ambitious initiative to produce, transform and export pineapple took shape with the support of the national government, the municipality of Tauramena and the oil companies Ecopetrol, Geopark, Parex and Oleoducto de los Llanos (ODL). the validation of traceability protocols, land preparation, placement of organic fertilizer and mulching for the subsequent planting of Gold MD2 pineapple.

 

The initiative was developed through the pineapple cluster led by the Casanare Chamber of Commerce and the work of the company Agrícola Santana de los Llanos.

 

Nearly 100 pineapple producers, mainly from that town and other municipalities in the department, were trained to learn about the benefits of the Tauramena pineapple for the world project.

 

The idea was to put into operation a pineapple processing plant to export it as fresh fruit, for pulp processing and other products such as the transformation of by-products into animal feed.

 

The processing center is located in the failed cassava processing plant in Tauramena and is the main center for reaching national and international pineapple markets.

 

The project received financial support from the ministries of Industry, Commerce and Tourism, and Agriculture, the municipality of Tauramena, and the oil companies, which contributed 5,239 million pesos.

 

The executive president of the Chamber of Commerce of Casanare, expressed that the Casanarean pine growers have advanced and today they have more than 400 hectares established which, coincidentally, is the minimum amount necessary for operability.

 

In the month of June 2019 this plant was put in capacity to operate in a first phase which is the enlistment of fresh fruit for export and, subsequently, the processing of food and concentrates for internal and external consumption was implemented.

 

The Casanareño pineapple entrepreneur Leonardo Ávila said that his company exported between five and six tons per month of dehydrated pineapple to Germany, Spain, Chile, Ecuador and Panama, among other countries, and with the project that was consolidated the idea is to export between 20 and 22 tons, reach more countries and be much more competitive.

pill.title: Organic pineapple enterprises in Casanare.
pill.content:
Company 'Agrícola Casa Linda

 

The company 'Agrícola Casa Linda' owned by Mr. Olegario Gutiérrez, located in the village of Bubuy in the municipality of Aguazul, is dedicated to the cultivation of organic products.

 

Mr. Olegario Gutiérrez has mentioned that his agricultural company is so far a successful experiment of what organic agriculture is and that despite the difficulties that this production system has in its exercise, it is worth betting on this production model that avoids the use of pesticides on crops, making healthier production for human consumption.

posts.title: Entrepreneurship with victims and demobilized combatants
posts.description: To learn about the meaning and types of entrepreneurship, organic products and success stories of the sector in the region.

pill.title: Content
pill.content:
1. Impact of the ventures.
2. Social enterprises.
3. Social entrepreneurship in Colombia.
4. The role of entrepreneurship in conflict and post-conflict.
5. Entrepreneurship with victims and demobilized in Casanare.

pill.title: INTRODUCTION
pill.content:
Welcome:


Since the beginning of humanity, the human being has had an instinct of conservation to perpetuate its existence, this has been carried out through interaction with those around him, because it would be very difficult to subsist without living in society. In this sense we can say that the human being is a social being by nature and relies on the help of his peers to be able to endure. The human being is in search of discovering new things to change his life, because he is always looking for innovation to be able to offer welfare to people and thus improve their living conditions, which has been made possible by setting objectives, goals and achievements that are resolved with the various capabilities and efforts that human beings have.


Being an entrepreneur is the attempt to improve life, that is to say, it does not only correspond to a particular interest, but to a higher one, which is to improve life in society. For what benefits some, can benefit others. Being an entrepreneur also implies adapting to the times in which one lives and at the same time being able to innovate what is established.


In the following lessons you will learn about the impacts of entrepreneurship and social entrepreneurship as well as success stories from the region.

pill.title: Impact of the undertakings.
pill.content:
Economic impact.


Entrepreneurship is one of the driving forces of the economy, since it boosts productive development. Worldwide, all countries that are committed to progress include entrepreneurship as a factor of development.


Entrepreneurship is the ability to identify and coordinate productive resources at the service of an innovative idea in order to materialize a business. The entrepreneurial movement fosters competition, variety, selection, cooperation, transformation, evolution, scientific and knowledge advancement, among other positive factors for a country.


There are certain conditions to generate a favorable environment in which entrepreneurs are stimulated and multiply in a society: economic freedom, guarantee of the right to property, policies and regulations related to the subject, education and training infrastructure, among others.


While it is true that entrepreneurship is not the only solution for economic development, it is the key to rescue, channel and accelerate the pace of growth and economic development of a country. This whole process generates a cycle that translates into:


ENTREPRENEURSHIP = ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT = MORE ENTREPRENEURSHIP


Social impact.


Entrepreneurship goes hand in hand with education and innovation. The entrepreneurial spirit has become an unequaled force for progress that seeks to be promoted for a better present and a sustainable future. Through the methodological development of projects, an entrepreneur will ensure the fulfillment of his objectives and, hand in hand with them, the strengthening of the society that drives and participates in his dream. 


When entrepreneurial projects are created, the initial impact is evidenced in the levels of social prosperity. For Luis Fernando Castro, former executive president of the Chamber of Commerce of Barranquilla, if a business meets the requirements of EAI (high impact entrepreneurship), it increases social mobility (set of movements or displacements made by individuals, families or social groups within a given socioeconomic system), there are better paid wages and higher levels of formal employment. It is therefore essential to develop entrepreneurship platforms that drive innovative projects to higher levels.

pill.title: Social enterprises.
pill.content:
A social entrepreneurship organization uses its resources and business knowledge to generate profits, not so much monetary, but to collaborate with the welfare of a society.


Nowadays, both consumption and business vision is changing. The rise of the Internet and social networks has broadened and brought closer the real panorama faced by society, creating a conscious consumer profile.


Many customers prefer to buy products from those who address these social issues. Several entrepreneurs are willing to change the course of business due to the clear need for change that is present today.


Social entrepreneurship as a business model.


It is a corporate modality carried out by innovative companies that use both, a sales business model and a focus on solving socioeconomic or environmental problems found in society.


Due to its structure, this method allows organizations to be self-sustainable, scalable and generate profits to continue investing in this type of venture.


Fundamental aspects of social entrepreneurship


Social entrepreneurship is in constant search of balancing the three fundamental aspects of its mission, which are:

 

 

  • Achieving its economic success.
  • Its raison d'être is based on social responsibility.
  • Commitment to the environment.


Characteristics of social entrepreneurship


For a business to be classified as a social enterprise, it must have at least the following elements:

 

 

  • Its main objective must be social welfare and the creation of promoting work for and with society.
  • Most of its profits and income must be reinvested in achieving the social objective.
  • Its social actions go above and beyond the profit motive.
  • It seeks to establish itself as a company through the use of commercial or business methods, such as marketing, advertising and, of   course, sales.
  • It provides jobs and opportunities for professional growth.
  • Establishes itself as a store (either physical or virtual) and offers products or services in the same way that traditional commercial   enterprises do.
  • It provides innovative solutions to real social problems and environments, i.e. its fight is against poverty, social exclusion, crime,     climate change, etc.

pill.title: Social enterprises.
pill.content:
How to make a social enterprise profitable?


You may think that this type of entrepreneurship is utopian and almost impossible because its structure is both for-profit and social welfare. 


However, conscious consumers are here to stay. The concern for a better and more sustainable world is becoming more and more explicit and many people are willing to cooperate to achieve it.


The need for social and environmental change, the considerable increase in conscious customers and the demand for products or services from socially responsible companies, mean that more and more organizations are taking this initiative.
Keep in mind that it is a company.

 

Although its purpose is social, it is still a company. That is why it must be managed as such.
That is to say, making coherent and controlled decisions, by means of an adequate administration, with publicity and a good strategy.


Make a market study.

 

Social and environmental problems are everywhere, however, you must validate that you can connect with people through your brand, product or service.


Analyze how far you can go with market research.


Remember the importance of sales.

As in any traditional business, you must sell. Yes, you can accept donations, but remember that you don't depend on them, so put your heart into your sales strategies.


Use everything in your power.

    - Find people who are willing to help you, as brand ambassadors;
    - Use a good digital marketing strategy.
    - Define your brand to connect with real customers;
    - Research how large traditional companies expand;
    - Use your imagination!

gallery.title: Social enterprise explained with apples and pears

pill.title: Social entrepreneurship in Colombia.
pill.content:
RECON is a Colombian non-profit organization that identifies, connects and strengthens social enterprises that transform realities and impact the sustainable economic and social development of vulnerable communities. The work of this entity is aligned with the vision of the Sustainable Development Goals and we work for the most vulnerable communities in the country, applying a territorial, ethnic and gender approach. In addition to having the support with the Government of Sweden, the United Nations Development Program UNDP and the United States Agency for International Development USAID.


It began in 2018 to diagnose the state of Social Entrepreneurship in Colombia. This radiography is a key strategy that allows civil society, government, private enterprise, academia, social entrepreneurs and international organizations to recognize and understand the dynamics of these social business models and thus build a large ecosystem of Social Entrepreneurship in Colombia.

 

These studies showed in 2021 that in the impact categories there was a 100% increase in the number of social enterprises working in education (24.1%) and environment (21.1%).


These respond to current problems of lack of access to education, pollution and climate crisis. However, the decrease in the number of social enterprises working in Orange Economy is striking, taking into account that in recent years it has been a category promoted by the Colombian State. It went from 16.8% in 2018 to 11.8% in 2020.


Regarding the populations benefited, it is highlighted that social entrepreneurship continues to impact mainly children and young people (57.9%). This result is consistent with the 24.1% working in education.


There is an advance in the number of social ventures working Gender Equity due to the growing work with women (from 10.6% in 2018 to 45.2% in 2020), which helps to improve their socioeconomic conditions and close gender gaps. In addition, the growing rural vocation of these enterprises is evident, contributing to the development of the Colombian countryside (5.1% in 2018 to 34.2% in 2020).


Faced with the context of violence, Social Entrepreneurship in Colombia is exposed from its creation to its development to patterns of violence, illegality and violation of Human Rights. This problem has increased by 5% in recent years, possibly due to the increase of dissidents, bacrim and common crime in the Post-Conflict context. In 2018, 26.4% of social enterprises operated in territories with the presence of illegal armed groups, currently amounting to 31.4%.


There is a reduction of 11% (from 33.5% to 22.5%) of social ventures that were motivated by the context of armed conflict for the creation of their social venture, which shows that the creation and development of social ventures is gradually changing the narrative of conflict for one of Post-Conflict and Peacebuilding.

pill.title: Social entrepreneurship in Colombia
pill.content:
Gender equity is not left behind in the social business model. Currently, 54.8% of social entrepreneurs are men led by men and 45.2% by women. This shows that Social Entrepreneurship continues to reduce gender inequality gaps, with a balanced proportion of women in power scenarios (1:1 ratio). Social Entrepreneurship attracts women entrepreneurs, who are leaders in their communities and transform territories. In conventional entrepreneurship, the ratio is estimated to be 2:1 in favor of men.


The voice of young people is heard loudly through Social Entrepreneurship. The highest percentage of social entrepreneurs in Colombia continues to be people between 18 and 35 years old (45.6% of social entrepreneurs). It is worth noting that, in the last two years, there has been a 6% increase in social entrepreneurship led by older adults.


The academic level of social entrepreneurs is one of the characteristics to be highlighted: Most social entrepreneurs have high levels of professional training and put it at the service of generating social and environmental value. 68.9% of social entrepreneurs are professionals (51.7% undergraduate and 17.2% postgraduate). However, there is an increase of 5.3% (from 3.4% to 9.8%) of social entrepreneurship that have not had access to higher education and are developed empirically, making it an alternative tool for economic and professional welfare in communities without higher education.


Social Entrepreneurship in figures.

 

  • According to the results of the diagnosis, social enterprises were identified in 28 of Colombia's 32 departments, with only the departments of San Andrés, Guainía, Amazonas and Vichada not represented.
  • The main purpose of social enterprises (83.3%) is to generate social value, above maximizing their profits. 
  • The leading regions in terms of number of initiatives are Central East and Bogota 33%, Caribbean 20%, Pacific 18%, and Eje Cafetero   and Antioquia 17%. 
  • 55.2% of the social enterprises have legal status, while 44.8% are in the informal sector.
  • 100% are benefiting one or more vulnerable populations. The most benefited populations are children and adolescents 57.9%, women 45.2%, rural population 34.2%, elderly 27.9% and victims of the conflict 23.1%, population with disabilities 16.7%, indigenous communities 16.1%, LGTBI population 15.4%, Afro-descendants, raizales and palenqueros 15%, former combatants 10.4% and   refugees and immigrants 4.4%.
  • Social entrepreneurs are mostly young professionals, with an equal distribution between men and women. However, 59.7% do not earn any income from social entrepreneurship. It is worrying that the training of social entrepreneurs is not reflected in their economic   remuneration and that, therefore, they cannot devote full time to their ventures.

pill.title: Social entrepreneurship in Colombia.
pill.content:
Social Entrepreneurship: a tool for Sustainable Peace


For RECON, the history of the armed conflict and the current Post-Conflict context in the country is fundamental to analyze Social Entrepreneurship, as it is an important particularity of this ecosystem in Colombia that makes it unique and requires a special approach for the consolidation of the social business model in the country. This approach represents a relevant milestone for the study of Social Entrepreneurship in the world, contributing to an alternative vision of its measurement as an engine to promote Peace Building.

 

The radiography shows that 22.5% of social entrepreneurship was motivated by the context of armed conflict. It also shows that 96.2% of the social entrepreneurs consider themselves as agents of change for peace building in their territory and 95% consider that they contribute to peace building and post-conflict through their ventures.


62.7% of the social enterprises are benefiting a population group that is a victim of the armed conflict, which shows how these business models contribute to the comprehensive reparation of victims. This impact is mainly on those displaced by violence and children and adolescents recruited by illegal groups.

gallery.title: Characteristics of social entrepreneurship in Colombia

pill.title: The role of entrepreneurship in conflict and post-conflict.
pill.content:
The peace agreement in Colombia (2016), signed by the Government and the insurgent group Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC), generated expectations in all areas of society, from the peasant sector that aspires to a recomposition of the countryside, its forms of property and work, to a democratic opening with political participation of all citizen sectors. In this way, the peace process is beneficial for the country, because it can lead, in addition to the cessation of the conflict and political reforms, to the opening of new sources of work and employment.


In this context, entrepreneurship plays an important role in the social and economic, national and local spheres, both for the civilian population and for the people involved in the reintegration process, as well as for the victims of the armed conflict in Colombia. 


Regarding entrepreneurship, framed in an entrepreneurial ecosystem to refer to a correlation of social forces where, although the entrepreneur may be the protagonist, he/she is also part of a productive, supportive and inclusive system, constituted by a set of practices and concepts that contribute to the achievement of a certain objective. Entrepreneurship can collaborate, to a great extent, in the effective reintegration into society of people who have surrendered their weapons, that is, to achieve the incorporation into society of people who have been placed outside the law, so that they are covered by legality and, likewise, enjoy the constitutional guarantees and rights.


Within the strategies of entrepreneurship related to the conflict and post-conflict period, public policies stand out, such as the Comprehensive Agrarian Development Policy, aimed at promoting the union of the regions and the socio-economic and equitable development of the country. 


Another is the Income Generation Program, as a component of the National Government's Public Policy for Attention to Displacement; it establishes psychosocial support for production, business advice for the formulation and development of the business plan and the delivery of non-reimbursable resources for financing (in accordance with the signing of commitments and social control).


Regarding the strategy of support from different entities to entrepreneurship, it is possible to optimize results through the formulation of entrepreneurship projects by women victims of the armed conflict, advocating for their reparation, with an active role in it.


Another way to create opportunities from business organizations for demobilized and conflict-affected people is through better education and training. The private sector can contribute by having good practices and corporate social responsibility strategies.


The lack of training brings economic disadvantages, such as low productivity, lower quality, poor customer service, waste of raw materials and underutilization of machines; as well as social behaviors such as absenteeism, unpunctuality, abandonment of the workplace, accidents, disability leave and even deaths.

pill.title: The entrepreneurship role in conflict and post-conflict.
pill.content:
For certain companies, entrepreneurship can lead to joint training of victims, displaced and reintegrated populations, which can open the way to generate spaces for integration and reconciliation; likewise, generate alliances to link peasants and victims as part of their supply chain, eliminating intermediaries, which represents a reduction in the cost structure for companies, and allows them to have control over their production chain.


Another strategy mentioned is related to business education as an input for entrepreneurship in conflict and post-conflict situations. For ex-combatants, the Colombian State offers technical support; companies that have agreements with the Colombian Agency for Reincorporation (ACR) provide training and advice to entrepreneurs; thus, the Aportando Tiempo program was created, in which companies delegate professionals in administration and management to be trained.


Entrepreneurial education has a transforming effect on people's behavior in a context of conflict and, therefore, alters their economic circumstances in a way that reduces the tendency to support conflict, with changes in attitudes and thinking about self-employment, with awareness of the multidisciplinary nature of entrepreneurship.


On the other hand, the constitution of cooperatives has also become a strategy to promote entrepreneurship in conflict and post-conflict contexts, since resources are available for ex-combatants to generate cooperatives and small micro-enterprises as sources of employment and income; those who are organized in guilds obtain greater benefits. The government dynamic of providing solutions to small groups has encouraged the proliferation of small trade associations, which, in the long term, instead of strengthening the struggle, has weakened them as a collective.


The social and solidarity economy can guarantee social peace with justice and equity, accompanied by government programs, policies and strategies to promote and strengthen association initiatives, which can be weak in their bonds of trust and solidarity due to the lack of conciliation of interests and conflicts, the unfair practices of capitalism, the low level of solidarity and associativity and individualism, which also weaken coexistence and collective production. However, as for the State, "it is also its duty to solve problems such as lack of opportunities, poverty and violence, which make associative models one of the few ways to get ahead, especially in rural territories.


The conflict has affected different sectors of the population, with whom, in the post-conflict period, entrepreneurship has also been promoted, such as the youth sector. (under Law 1014 of 2006 or Law for the Promotion of the Culture of Entrepreneurship).


Law 1780 of 2016 or also known as Pro-Youth Law, was enacted with the objective of generating employment for young people aged between 18 and 28 years, through the design and implementation of employment policies, entrepreneurship and the creation of new young companies, along with the promotion of mechanisms that positively impact on the labor linkage of the young population in Colombia.

pill.title: The entrepreneurship role in conflict and post-conflict.
pill.content:
There is also entrepreneurship in indigenous populations. The great variety of indigenous communities and their cultural richness in Colombia, requires an analysis of the factors that affect the profile to be identified and that seeks the promotion of entrepreneurship and associativity. The idea of entrepreneurship in the indigenous population at the national level could be welcomed at the time of projecting development programs for their sustainability and community progress. This indicates that the profile of the indigenous entrepreneur in the country can be characterized by preserving traditional traits; based on this characteristic, productive activities can be generated in the short, medium and long term. For these processes to achieve the desired impact, entrepreneurship and associativity must be stimulated so that the individual or the community become involved voluntarily and taking into account all the cultural, traditional and social variables of each population.


Therefore, in order to develop programs to promote entrepreneurship, associativity and productivity in indigenous communities, these should focus on their wisdom and tradition, taking into account schools for the transmission of their own knowledge, where the older indigenous people spread their wisdom among young people and children, so that they are not unaware of their history as their main heritage and, on this basis, encourage productive activities. In the new stage that Colombia is beginning, displaced indigenous people will return to their territories of origin and entrepreneurship can contribute to the reconstruction of these scenarios.
Some types of entrepreneurship that can be promoted with people or groups reincorporated after the conflict and in the post-conflict period may be:


Tourism entrepreneurship. At the Colombian level, research was carried out to extract the weaknesses, threats, strengths and opportunities of the Department of Chocó, and a series of actions were proposed to mitigate the impacts on the territory and identify possible scenarios in which demobilized combatants could be included in the labor market. Once the natural attractions of the intervention area were identified, a sustainable tourism product was created, which involved the design of hiking trails - where the demobilized combatants were chosen as guides, since they know the territory - and the design of tourist routes to the Atrato River, since it connects communities on its banks, which will encourage community tourism in the area.


In addition, the potentials and limitations of social entrepreneurship to achieve inclusive tourism are investigated, although in Colombia, this has limitations. Together, continued social benefits depend on the commercial success of enterprises in a highly volatile sector and, in the case of Colombia's Pacific coast region, in a state of almost continuous violence; even well-managed businesses that are not completely safe. There are conventional tourism businesses - a tourism company, a hotel, a restaurant, a souvenir production and retail sales - that have integrated a social mission into their business model in different ways.


Rural entrepreneurship. In terms of reinsertion and reintegration, the amnestied persons benefited from land delivery programs, support for rural housing, credits and some social care commitments. Thus, they tended to return to the countryside, in productive activities, in places other than those where they were part of the guerrillas, and, equally, they often stood out for their social leadership.

pill.title: The entrepreneurship role in conflict and post-conflict.
pill.content:
Alternative development programs seek to move farmers away from the production of high-value commodities such as coca and poppy to others such as coffee and nuts, but have had mixed results, largely without success. There is also the problem of program sustainability and management, because several DDR programs have failed when, after the transition from international actors to local authorities, compensations were mismanaged, reduced or stopped.


In conclusion, entrepreneurship is related not only to the creation of enterprises as it is commonly associated, but also to the growth of individuals and communities, by engaging in an environment of education and culture, as an attitude based on knowledge and entrepreneurial practices.


Furthermore, entrepreneurship is an alternative for the solution of real problems faced by the population in the reintegration process, as well as by the victims of the conflict, since it not only benefits a particular person, but also fosters the development of the entire community, improves the quality of life of families and promotes innovation to add value to products.


On the other hand, the role of education in entrepreneurship processes has become fundamental, as it accompanies the formulation of projects with their objectives, goals, strategies and actions that link this sector with the problems of society and, in particular, with the processes of cessation of the armed conflict and the subsequent period of peace.


Although entrepreneurship constitutes a valid strategy of inclusion and productivity for people in the process of reintegration into society, this requires an educational process for the appropriation of concepts and practices for the creation of businesses and productive projects.
Within the entrepreneurship for victims and ex-combatants, different types are proposed taking into account the potential of the regions where they are located, for example, tourism, rural, cultural, social and other entrepreneurship.


Immigrants and displaced persons in Colombia and other countries tend to have higher rates of self-employment than natives. The entrepreneurship and small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) policies seek to encourage training in entrepreneurship as self-employment or small business ownership.

pill.title: Entrepreneurship with victims and demobilized combatants in Casanare.
pill.content:
In the municipality of Sácama, Casanare, a group of 21 women belonging to population groups such as mothers who are heads of households, victims of the armed conflict, and those with disabilities seek to change the reality of their community by transforming the coffee business to help more women.


This is the Association of Enterprising Women of Sácama (AGROMESACA), who through female community empowerment formed a coffee growing enterprise which has been in high demand nationally and internationally.


The product stood out for its quality, flavor and aroma, which allowed it to be taken to the Netherlands and to be chosen as the official coffee of the embassy in Colombia.


Yanet Ayala, coordinator of the project assures that this has been a way to leave behind an armed conflict that has damaged the women of the region and to build on the talent and the desire of the members to move forward.


Currently this enterprise is looking for a way to have its own place to market all its products along with the tools and land to achieve a larger scale production. The pandemic has restricted the logistics of product sales, and the current National Strike has left them stranded in some parts of the country.


However, the project is growing and they seek to position their coffee as one of the best nationally and internationally.

Did you know...


In 2019, the coffee brand 'Espíritu de Paz' (coffee produced by former FARC combatants and victims of the conflict in Cauca) was named the best coffee in the world.

 

The aroma, body and flavor of the coffee grown in the mountains of northern Cauca, conquered the palates of the jury over five thousand other samples worldwide.
